• The Child’s Critical Illness Benefit ends on the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s youngest child’s 19th birthday
• The Child’s Critical Illness Benefit is not payable if the Plan ends or is cancelled.
This benefit is not available when structured through superannuation.
A benefit payment of $10,000 will be payable under the Child’s Critical Illness Benefit if your child suffers a Child’s Critical Illness Event listed under Child’s Critical Illness Insurance (Section 2.5). Each event is defined in Section 9. For a benefit to be paid, the specified serious event must meet the full criteria and severity requirements for that event.
ai_summary: The Child's Critical Illness Benefit provides a one-time payment of $10,000 for eligible children aged 2 to 19 who suffer from specified critical illnesses, subject to a three-month qualifying period. Key conditions include financial dependency on the policy owner, the benefit being payable only once per child across all plans, and exclusions for events occurring before the child's first birthday or prior to the policy start date. The benefit ceases when the youngest child turns 19, and it is not available through superannuation or if the plan is canceled. For payment, the event must meet defined criteria outlined in the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content: These options only apply if stated in the Policy Schedule.
ai_summary: Section 2.4.2 outlines that optional benefits for Life, Total and Permanent Disability (TPD), and Critical Illness Insurance are only applicable if explicitly specified in the Policy Schedule. This emphasizes the importance of reviewing the Policy Schedule to understand which additional benefits may be available under the insurance policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
Under the Premium Relief Option, premiums due in relation to a Life Insured will be waived when, because of Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is for three consecutive months:
• totally unable to work in any occupation for which he or she is suited by training, education or experience;
• not earning an income; and
• following the advice of a Medical Practitioner.
You must notify us in writing of your intention to exercise the Premium Relief Option. You will also be required to provide to us the necessary evidence which (in our reasonable opinion) confirms your health/ medical, employment and financial status.
The amount waived will be the daily proportion of premiums due. The Premium Relief Option will stop on the earlier of:
• the Life Insured is capable of working in any occupation for which he or she is suited by training, education or experience;
• the Life Insured generating Earnings; or
• the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday.
ai_summary: The Premium Relief Option allows for the waiver of life insurance premiums when the insured is totally unable to work for three consecutive months due to sickness or injury, is not earning an income, and is following medical advice. To activate this option, written notification and evidence of health, employment, and financial status must be provided. The waiver applies to the daily proportion of premiums and will cease when the insured can work, generates income, or reaches the policy anniversary before turning 65.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
No premiums will be waived under the Premium Relief Option if the claim is caused:
• directly or indirectly by an intentional, self-inflicted act by the Life Insured; or
• by normal and uncomplicated pregnancy, miscarriage or childbirth. Normal and uncomplicated pregnancy includes, but is not limited to morning sickness, backache, varicose veins, ankle swelling, bladder problems, carpal tunnel syndrome, multiple pregnancy, or participation in an IVF or similar program.
The Premium Relief Option is not available after any of the following have been exercised:
• Death Buy-Back Option;
• Death Buy-Back Benefit; or
• Critical Illness Reinstatement Option.
ai_summary: The Premium Relief Option for Life, TPD, and Critical Illness Insurance does not waive premiums for claims resulting from intentional self-inflicted acts or normal pregnancy-related conditions. Additionally, this option becomes unavailable after exercising the Death Buy-Back Option, Death Buy-Back Benefit, or Critical Illness Reinstatement Option.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
Not available when structured through superannuation.
The Business Insurance Option is available under Life Insurance and is only applicable to Critical Illness Insurance and/ or TPD Insurances when Attached to Life Insurance.
Under the Business Insurance Option, you can apply to increase the Benefit Amount without the need for further evidence of health, or pastimes, subject to acceptable financial evidence being provided.
The Business Insurance Option is available when one of the following business events occurs:
ai_summary: The Business Insurance Option allows policyholders to increase their Benefit Amount for Life Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, and TPD Insurance without additional health evidence, provided acceptable financial documentation is submitted. This option is not available when the insurance is structured through superannuation and can be activated upon specific business events.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
Business event | Description
---|---
Business value | An increase in the Life Insured’s share or value of the business entity for which this cover was originally established.
Key-person value | An increase in the value of the Life Insured key person to the business entity for which the cover was originally established.
Loan guarantee | An increase in the level of a business loan for which the Life Insured is a guarantor.
ai_summary: The Premium Relief Option under Life, TPD, and Critical Illness Insurance provides additional benefits related to business events, including an increase in the Life Insured's share or value of the business, the enhanced value of a key person to the business, and an increase in the level of a business loan for which the Life Insured acts as a guarantor. These provisions ensure that the insurance coverage adapts to significant changes in the business landscape, safeguarding the financial interests of the insured and the business entity.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
The total Benefit Amount after all increases cannot exceed three times the Benefit Amount (including cover with TAL and any other organisation) at the Plan start date and following limits:
• Life Insurance: $15 million.
• TPD Insurance: $3 million.
• Critical Illness Insurance: $2 million.
The following conditions also apply to Business Insurance Option:
• Increases for TPD Insurance and Critical Illness Insurance will not be allowed if the business event occurred or the application for increase is submitted to us after the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 60th birthday.
• You must apply in writing within 30 days of the business event occurring or within 30 days of the Policy anniversary following the business event.
• Any application for an increase will be assessed using the same valuation method used in the application for the Business Insurance Option. The assessment of the application to increase the Benefit Amount will also include an analysis of the business’s growth and business profitability trends. Your application for increase may be declined if the business trend indicates that the business has not grown, is in decline or net profit is decreasing.
• If the application for increase is due to a ‘loan guarantee’, the increased Benefit Amount cannot exceed the amount by which the ‘loan guarantee’ has increased.
• The application to increase the Benefit Amount must not exceed the increase in value resulting from the business event. If the application to increase the Benefit Amount is less than the increase in value resulting from the business event, any subsequent applications to increase the Benefit Amount will only be allowed if the subsequent valuation of the business is greater than the last valuation that was used to increase the Benefit Amount under Business Insurance Option.
• Any application to increase the Benefit Amount under the Business Insurance Option must be for the same business event for which the Policy was originally established as determined by us.
• If the Benefit Amount at the Plan start date is less than 100% of the value associated with the purpose of the business insurance, we will limit any future increases made under the Business Insurance Option such that the amount insured, as a proportion of the value associated with the business insurance purpose, does not increase above that which applied at the Plan start date.
ai_summary: The Premium Relief Option for Life, TPD, and Critical Illness Insurance imposes a maximum Benefit Amount of $15 million for Life Insurance, $3 million for TPD Insurance, and $2 million for Critical Illness Insurance, with total coverage not exceeding three times the initial Benefit Amount. For Business Insurance, increases in TPD and Critical Illness coverage are restricted if requested after the Policy anniversary preceding the Life Insured's 60th birthday, and applications must be submitted within 30 days of the relevant business event. Additionally, any increase requests will be evaluated based on business growth and profitability, and must align with the original purpose of the insurance policy, ensuring that future increases do not surpass the initial coverage proportion relative to the business's value

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
ai_summary: The Business Insurance Option allows for an increase in the Benefit Amount for Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) and Critical Illness Insurance, necessitating a corresponding increase in the Attached Life Insurance. However, this option cannot be exercised if the Life Insured is currently entitled to a claim or payment from any life, TPD, critical illness, or income protection insurance, and it can only be utilized once every 12 months. Additionally, if the Business Insurance Option is included in the Policy Schedule, several benefits, such as Inflation Protection and Guaranteed Future Insurability, will not apply until the option is canceled.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
Any application to increase the Benefit Amount under Business Insurance Option must be accompanied with the following information:
• Confirmation the Life Insured is actively at work in their usual occupation at the time of application.
• A current valuation of the business provided by a qualified accountant or business valuer, which we reasonably consider to be acceptable. The business valuation method used must be consistent across all valuations.
• Financial or occupational evidence in support of the application.

The Business Insurance Option ends on the earlier of the following:
• If the option is cancelled by you.
• A benefit being paid under Life Insurance, TPD Insurance or Critical Illness Insurance as a result of the Life Insured suffering a Sickness or Injury.
• The maximum increase limit has been reached.
• The death of the Life Insured.
• Life Insurance is cancelled.
• The Policy anniversary prior to the Life Insured attaining age 65.
• The third Policy anniversary, if the Business Insurance Option is not exercised within the first three years from the Plan start date.
• The third Policy anniversary from the date Business Insurance Option was last exercised. However, we will extend the Business Insurance Option for another three years (from the date we accept the financial evidence) if you provide financial evidence, which we reasonably consider to be acceptable, that the Business Insurance Option could not be exercised because none of the business events described above occurred. The evidence must be provided to us within 30 days of the end of the option expiring.
ai_summary: To increase the Benefit Amount under the Business Insurance Option, applicants must confirm the Life Insured is actively working, provide a current business valuation from a qualified professional, and submit supporting financial or occupational evidence. The option terminates upon cancellation, payment of benefits due to the Life Insured's Sickness or Injury, reaching the maximum increase limit, the Life Insured's death, cancellation of Life Insurance, or specific policy anniversaries, unless extended under certain conditions with acceptable financial evidence.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Child’s Critical Illness Insurance only applies if indicated in your Policy Schedule. Child’s Critical Illness Insurance cannot be structured through superannuation.
A benefit under Child’s Critical Illness Insurance will only be paid if the conditions and requirements for a claimable event are met after the Plan start date and before the Plan end date.
A benefit under Child’s Critical Illness Insurance will only be paid if the Child Insured suffers a specified serious event as described in the sections below. We require confirmation of diagnosis by a Medical Practitioner and the specified severity threshold criteria to be met, for a benefit to be payable. The severity threshold criteria are defined for each event in Section 9.
For many specified serious events this means the condition will be required to progress beyond a diagnosis, where diagnosis means the process of a Medical Practitioner determining which Sickness or Injury explains an individual’s symptoms. You must also satisfy our claim requirements in Section 3 of this PDS.
When we refer to a benefit payment, the statement is made on the basis that the benefit referred to is payable under the terms and conditions of the Policy.
ai_summary: Child's Critical Illness Insurance is applicable only if specified in the Policy Schedule and cannot be funded through superannuation. Benefits are payable only if the insured child experiences a defined serious event after the Plan start date and before the Plan end date, with a confirmed diagnosis from a Medical Practitioner and adherence to severity threshold criteria outlined in Section 9. Additionally, all claim requirements in Section 3 must be satisfied for a benefit payment to be issued, which is contingent upon meeting the policy's terms and conditions.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Child’s Critical Illness Benefit
The Benefit Amount will be paid if the Child Insured suffers a Child’s Critical Illness Event listed below after the Plan start date and before the Plan end date.
The sum of all payments per child under the Child’s Critical Illness Insurance and Child’s Critical Illness Benefit (where applicable), including cover with TAL and any other organisation will be limited to $250,000.
If the Child Insured suffers more than one Child’s Critical Illness Event, the Benefit Amount is only paid for the Child’s Critical Illness Event that occurs first.
ai_summary: The Child's Critical Illness Insurance provides a Benefit Amount for a Child Insured diagnosed with a specified critical illness after the policy's start date and before its end date, with total payments capped at $250,000 across all policies. If multiple critical illness events occur, benefits will only be paid for the first event diagnosed.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Child’s Critical Illness Events
Heart conditions
• Cardiomyopathy (permanent)
• Heart Attack (of specified severity)¹
Neurological conditions
• Coma (of specified severity)
• Encephalitis (resulting in permanent neurological deficit)
• Major Head Trauma (with permanent neurological deficit)
• Meningitis (resulting in permanent neurological deficit)
• Meningococcal Septicaemia (resulting in significant permanent impairment)
• Paralysis (permanent)
• Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit)¹
Permanent conditions
• Blindness (permanent)
• Deafness (permanent)
• Loss of use of Limbs (permanent)
• Loss of Speech (permanent)
Cancer
• Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit)¹
• Cancer (of specified criteria)¹
Organ Disorder
• Chronic Kidney Failure (undergoing permanent dialysis)
• Major Organ Transplant (of specified organs)
• Severe Burns (covering at least 20% of the body’s surface area)
Other events
• Aplastic Anaemia (requiring treatment)
• Death
• Terminal Illness
¹A three month qualifying period applies. Refer to the ‘When we will not pay’ Section 2.5.2 for details.
ai_summary: The Child's Critical Illness Insurance covers a range of serious health conditions, including specific heart and neurological disorders, permanent disabilities (such as blindness and paralysis), certain cancers, and organ disorders like chronic kidney failure and major organ transplants. Notably, a three-month qualifying period applies to certain conditions, as detailed in Section 2.5.2 regarding exclusions.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If we pay the Child’s Critical Illness Benefit, we will reimburse the costs of up to three grief counselling sessions for an Immediate Family Member of the Child Insured with a counsellor approved by us, acting reasonably (the counsellor should be competent, recognised and appropriately qualified to provide the support). The maximum total amount we will reimburse under the Grief Support Benefit is $1,000.
This benefit must be exercised within 12 months of the Benefit Amount being paid.
ai_summary: The Grief Support Benefit under the Child's Critical Illness Insurance provides reimbursement for up to three grief counseling sessions for an Immediate Family Member of the insured child, with a maximum reimbursement of $1,000. To qualify, the sessions must be conducted by a counsellor approved by the insurer and completed within 12 months of the Child's Critical Illness Benefit payment.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If the Child’s Critical Illness Insurance Plan has not ceased prior to the Plan end date, the Child Insured can apply for a new Life Insurance Plan with Attached Critical Illness Insurance Standard Plan without requiring further medical information, except for smoking status, height, weight and occupation. The application must be made to us in writing within 30 days of the Plan end date. If Critical Illness Insurance Standard is not available, we will provide a Plan we believe is most like Critical Illness Insurance Standard.
The Life Insurance with Attached Critical Illness Insurance Standard (or other replacement cover) can be purchased on the following basis:
• The Benefit Amount will be the same or less than the Child’s Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount. Any increase to the Benefit Amount will be subject to full Underwriting.
• No options will be available. Selection of optional benefits will be subject to full Underwriting.
• The Inflation Protection Benefit (or equivalent) and the Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit (or equivalent) will not apply.
• A new premium rate will apply based on the premium rates and rating factors applicable to Life Insurance and Critical Illness Insurance Standard at the time the option is exercised.
• Any special conditions or loadings applied to Child’s Critical Illness Insurance will continue to apply.
These conditions override the terms of any new or continued Policy arising from the exercising of the continuation option under the Child’s Critical Illness Option.
ai_summary: The Child's Critical Illness Insurance Plan allows the Child Insured to apply for a new Life Insurance Plan with Attached Critical Illness Insurance Standard without additional medical information (except for smoking status, height, weight, and occupation) if the application is submitted in writing within 30 days of the Plan end date. The new coverage will have a Benefit Amount equal to or less than the existing one, with no optional benefits available, and will be subject to a new premium rate based on current factors. Existing special conditions from the original plan will continue to apply, and if the Critical Illness Insurance Standard is unavailable, a similar alternative will be provided.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Child's Critical Illness Events where qualifying period applies
content:
• Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit)
• Cancer (of specified criteria)
• Heart Attack (of specified severity)
• Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit);
ai_summary: Section 2.5 outlines the qualifying events for Child's Critical Illness Insurance, which include a benign brain tumor leading to irreversible neurological deficits, cancer meeting specified criteria, a heart attack of defined severity, and a stroke resulting in neurological deficits. Coverage for these conditions is contingent upon meeting the specified criteria and conditions outlined in the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: 2.5.3 When Child's Critical Illness Insurance ends
ai_summary: Child's Critical Illness Insurance terminates and the insurer's liability ends on the earliest of the following events: the policy anniversary before the Child Insured turns 23, receipt of a written cancellation request from the Policy Owner, cancellation due to non-payment of premiums, cancellation due to misrepresentation or fraudulent claims, the death of the Child Insured, or upon payment of the full Benefit Amount.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: No payment will be made if the Child’s Critical Illness Event arises directly or indirectly because of an intentional act of a person who stands to derive a benefit from the claim payment.
ai_summary: Payment under the Child's Critical Illness Insurance will be denied if the critical illness event is caused directly or indirectly by an intentional act of an individual who would benefit from the claim.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
No payment will be made if a claim arises directly or indirectly because of any one of the Child’s Critical Illness Events listed in the table below if the condition or event occurred or was diagnosed, or signs or symptoms leading to the diagnosis became apparent:
• within three months after the Plan start date;
• within three months after the date of an approved applied-for increase, but only in respect of the increase portion; or
• within three months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate the Plan.
ai_summary: Claims for Child's Critical Illness Insurance will not be paid if the critical illness event occurs or is diagnosed within three months of the Plan start date, an approved increase, or the most recent reinstatement date. This qualifying period applies specifically to conditions related to the increase portion of coverage.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Income Protection only applies if 'Income Protection Plan' is indicated in your Policy Schedule. Any applicable options are shown in your Policy Schedule.
Income Protection conditions are set out in this section of this PDS.
A benefit under Income Protection will only be paid if the condition and requirements for a claimable event are met after the Plan start date and before the Plan end date, unless stated otherwise.
Income Protection can be structured through superannuation or outside superannuation. When Income Protection is structured through superannuation, the SIS legislation and rules will apply, and some benefits may not be payable if your circumstances do not meet the SIS legislation and rules requirements. When this occurs, we will assess any eligibility to a benefit payment under the additional Policy structured outside superannuation if Superlink IP applies.
When we refer to a benefit payment, we mean a benefit payment which is paid in accordance with the terms and conditions of this Policy. We will not make a benefit payment if an exclusion or special condition applies. You must also satisfy the claim requirements in Section 3 of this PDS.
Where Income Protection has been structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition for Temporary Incapacity or Permanent Incapacity.
ai_summary: Income Protection coverage is applicable only if specified in the Policy Schedule, with benefits contingent on meeting claim conditions between the Plan start and end dates. This coverage can be structured through superannuation, subject to SIS legislation, which may affect benefit eligibility; if ineligible, an assessment will be made under the Policy structured outside superannuation. Benefit payments are contingent upon compliance with the Policy's terms, and exclusions or special conditions may apply. Additionally, for superannuation-structured Income Protection, the Life Insured must meet SIS definitions for Temporary or Permanent Incapacity.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: What does Partially Unable to Work mean
content:
Partially Unable to Work means that solely because of Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is:
• working (whether or not for remuneration) in a reduced capacity or capable of working in a reduced capacity;
• following the advice and treatment plan of a Medical Practitioner in relation to the Sickness or Injury; and
• not capable of working more than 80% of the Life Insured’s usual average working hours in the 12 months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period. The usual average working hours immediately before the start of the Waiting Period will be limited to 40 hours a week (if the Life Insured is working more than 40 hours a week).
ai_summary: Partially Unable to Work refers to a situation where, due to Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is either working or capable of working in a reduced capacity, is adhering to a Medical Practitioner’s treatment plan, and cannot work more than 80% of their usual average hours from the 12 months prior to the Waiting Period, which is capped at 40 hours per week if they typically work more.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: How do you qualify for the benefits?
content:
Occupation class AAA, AA+, AA and A (as indicated in the Policy Schedule)
To qualify for the Totally Unable to Work Benefit, the Life Insured must:
• be Totally Unable to Work for at least 7 consecutive days during the Waiting Period;
• remain Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work for the balance of the Waiting Period; and
• remain Totally Unable to Work at the end of the Waiting Period.
To qualify for the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, the Life Insured must:
• be Totally Unable to Work for at least 7 consecutive days during the Waiting Period;
• remain Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work for the balance of the Waiting Period; and
• remain Partially Unable to Work at the end of the Waiting Period.
ai_summary: To qualify for the Totally Unable to Work Benefit under the Income Protection policy for occupation classes AAA, AA+, AA, and A, the Life Insured must be Totally Unable to Work for a minimum of 7 consecutive days during the Waiting Period and remain Totally or Partially Unable to Work throughout the Waiting Period, with continued Total Disability at its conclusion. For the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, the same initial condition applies, but the Life Insured must be Partially Unable to Work by the end of the Waiting Period.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
ai_summary: The Income Protection policy offers three main benefits: the Totally Unable to Work Benefit, the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, and the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit, which is available under the IP Enhance option after the Claim Period has reached a minimum of 24 months.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: What does Totally Unable to Work mean?
content:
Totally Unable to Work means that solely because of Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is:
• not working in any capacity (this includes full-time, part-time and casual, whether or not for remuneration);
• following the advice and treatment plan of a Medical Practitioner in relation to the Sickness or Injury, and
• unable to perform all the duties necessary to generate income in the Life Insured’s Own Occupation* (if the Life Insured is able to perform any duties necessary to generate income in their Own Occupation*, they are not Totally Unable to Work).
*If the ‘to age 65’ Benefit Period applies, following the first 24 months of the Claim Period, Own Occupation will be replaced with Any Occupation.
ai_summary: "Totally Unable to Work" refers to the condition where the Life Insured, due to Sickness or Injury, is completely unable to engage in any work—full-time, part-time, or casual—while adhering to a Medical Practitioner’s treatment plan. Additionally, they must be unable to perform all duties required to generate income in their Own Occupation; if they can perform any duties, they do not qualify as Totally Unable to Work. Notably, if the 'to age 65' Benefit Period is applicable, after 24 months, the definition shifts from Own Occupation to Any Occupation.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Occupation class BBB, BB, B and SRA (as indicated in the Policy Schedule)
content:
To qualify for the Totally Unable to Work Benefit, the Life Insured must:
• be Totally Unable to Work for at least 14 consecutive days during the Waiting Period;
• remain Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work for the balance of the Waiting Period; and
• remain Totally Unable to Work at the end of the Waiting Period.
ai_summary: To qualify for the Totally Unable to Work Benefit under the Income Protection policy for occupation classes BBB, BB, B, and SRA, the Life Insured must be Totally Unable to Work for a minimum of 14 consecutive days during the Waiting Period, continue to be Totally or Partially Unable to Work for the remainder of the Waiting Period, and remain Totally Unable to Work at the end of this period.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Partially Unable to Work Benefit Qualification and Commencement
content:
To qualify for the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, the Life Insured must:
• be Totally Unable to Work for at least 14 consecutive days during the Waiting Period;
• remain Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work for the balance of the Waiting Period; and
• remain Partially Unable to Work at the end of the Waiting Period.

When will the benefits start to accrue and become payable?
The Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit:
• start to accrue after the Waiting Period ends; and
• are payable monthly in arrears.
ai_summary: To qualify for the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, the Life Insured must be Totally Unable to Work for at least 14 consecutive days during the Waiting Period, continue to be Totally or Partially Unable to Work for the remainder of this period, and remain Partially Unable to Work at its conclusion. Benefits commence accruing after the Waiting Period and are payable monthly in arrears.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: How much is payable and what are the requirements for ongoing benefit payments?
content:
Once you qualify for the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, the amount payable depends on the income replacement option selected (refer to the applicable table below). The income replacement options available are:
• Income Protection Focus;
• Income Protection Enhance; and
• Income Protection Extend.

The income replacement option selected is shown in the Policy Schedule. In calculating the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, the benefit payable cannot exceed the Totally Unable to Work Benefit.

The amount payable under the Totally Unable to Work Benefit and the Partially Unable to Work Benefit may be reduced if an offset applies (refer to Section 2.6.5 for details) and/or an adjustment (refer to ‘When we will adjust your benefit payments’ section below).

The tables below shows:
• Changes to the occupation definition used to determine the Life Insured’s capacity to work as the duration of the Claim Period increases.
• The benefit payable under the Totally Unable to Work Benefit, including changes to the Benefit Amount as the duration of the Claim Period increases.
• The benefit payable under the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, including changes to the Benefit Amount and formula as the duration of the Claim Period increases.
ai_summary: In Section 2.6 of the Income Protection policy, benefits are categorized into Totally Unable to Work and Partially Unable to Work, with payment amounts determined by the selected income replacement option: Income Protection Focus, Enhance, or Extend. The benefit amount may be adjusted based on offsets or changes in the definition of work capacity as the claim period progresses, and the Partially Unable to Work Benefit cannot exceed the Totally Unable to Work Benefit. Detailed tables outline the benefit amounts and adjustments over time.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
This table outlines the occupation definition and benefit payments for Income Protection Focus.

Claim Period
| | 1 – 24 months | After 24 months (5 year Benefit Period only) |
|---|---|---|
| Occupation definition used in Totally Unable to Work definition | Own Occupation | Own Occupation |
| When the Waiting Period starts before Policy anniversary before 60th birthday | Totally Unable to Work Benefit Payable¹ | Benefit Amount |
| | Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable¹,² | Benefit Amount less 75% of Earnings |
| When the Waiting Period starts after Policy anniversary before 60th birthday | Totally Unable to Work Benefit payable¹ | Benefit Amount | 2/3rd of Benefit Amount |
| | Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable¹,² | Benefit Amount less 75% of Earnings when Partially Unable to Work | 2/3rd of Benefit Amount less 75% of Earnings when Partially Unable to Work |

¹The amount payable may be reduced if an offset applies (refer to Section 2.6.5 for details).
²The amount payable may be subject to an adjustment (refer to 'When we will adjust your benefit payments' section below).
ai_summary: The Income Protection Focus table details the definitions of occupation and benefit payments for claims based on the policyholder's ability to work. For claims within the first 24 months, benefits are based on the "Totally Unable to Work" or "Partially Unable to Work" definitions, with specific amounts payable depending on the waiting period and whether the policyholder is partially unable to work. After 24 months, benefits continue under the same definitions but are adjusted, with a maximum of two-thirds of the benefit amount applicable for certain conditions. Reductions may apply based on offsets or adjustments as outlined in the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
This table outlines the occupation definition, benefit payments, and Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit for Income Protection Enhance.

Claim Period
| | 1 – 24 months | After 24 months |
|---|---|---|
| Occupation definition used in Totally Unable to Work definition | Own Occupation | Any Occupation |
| Totally Unable to Work Benefit payable¹ | Benefit Amount | 2/3rd of Benefit Amount |
| Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable¹,² | Benefit Amount less 75% of Earnings when Partially Unable to Work | 2/3rd of Benefit Amount less 100% of Earnings when Partially Unable to Work |
| Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit¹,³ | Not applicable | 1/3rd of Benefit Amount |

¹The amount payable may be reduced if an offset applies (refer to Section 2.6.5 for details).
²The amount payable may be subject to an adjustment (refer to 'When we will adjust your benefit payments' section below).
³Refer to the 'Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit' section below for details.
ai_summary: The Income Protection Enhance (IP Enhance) table specifies that during the first 24 months of a claim, benefits are based on the insured's own occupation, with full benefit amounts payable for total incapacity, while after 24 months, benefits shift to any occupation with reduced payouts. Additionally, for partial incapacity, benefits are adjusted based on earnings, and a Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit is available after 24 months, amounting to one-third of the benefit amount, subject to potential offsets and adjustments as detailed in the document.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
This table outlines the occupation definition and benefit payments for Income Protection Extend.

Claim Period
| | 1 – 24 months | After 24 months |
|---|---|---|
| Occupation definition used in Totally Unable to Work definition | Own Occupation | Any Occupation |
| When the Waiting Period starts before Policy anniversary before 60th birthday | Totally Unable to Work Benefit Payable¹ | Benefit Amount |
| | Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable¹,² | Benefit Amount less 75% of Earnings | Benefit Amount less 100% of Earnings |
| When the Waiting Period starts after Policy anniversary before 60th birthday | Totally Unable to Work Benefit payable¹ | Benefit Amount | 2/3rd of Benefit Amount |
| | Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable¹,² | Benefit Amount less 75% of Earnings when Partially Unable to Work | 2/3rd of Benefit Amount less 100% of Earnings when Partially Unable to Work |

¹The amount payable may be reduced if an offset applies (refer to Section 2.6.5 for details).
²The amount payable may be subject to an adjustment (refer to 'When we will adjust your benefit payments' section below).
ai_summary: The Income Protection Extend (IP Extend) table specifies benefit payments based on the claimant's occupation status over two periods: 1-24 months and after 24 months. For claims initiated before the policyholder's 60th birthday, benefits for "Totally Unable to Work" are based on "Own Occupation" for the first 24 months, transitioning to "Any Occupation" thereafter. Payments may be adjusted based on earnings, with specific reductions for "Partially Unable to Work." Additionally, benefits may be subject to offsets and adjustments as detailed in other sections of the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Only available if IP Enhance option is shown in your Policy Schedule.
The purpose of the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit is to provide an additional support payment in the event that the Life Insured suffers Serious and Permanent Incapacity.
The Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit is only available once the total Claim Period has reached 24 months or more for a claim.
The Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit is payable when the Life Insured:
• has achieved Maximum Medical Improvement of the Sickness or Injury;
• is entitled to the Totally Unable to Work Benefit; and
• is Seriously and Permanently Incapacitated* (see Section 9 for definition).
*Any claim for a mental illness under the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit will only be assessed under the ‘mental illness’ category under the Serious and Permanent Incapacity definition.
For the Life Insured to qualify for the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit on an ongoing basis, the Life Insured must continuously meet the requirements for the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit.
The Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit payable will be 1/3rd of the Benefit Amount for each month the Life Insured is eligible for the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit and is payable monthly in arrears. The Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit will be paid in addition to the Totally Unable to Work Benefit, less any other payments (see Section 2.6.5).
The Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit will stop on the earlier of the following events:
• the date the Life Insured is no longer Seriously and Permanently Incapacitated;
• the date the Life Insured is no longer Totally Unable to Work;
• the end of the Benefit Period; or
• the Life Insured’s 65th birthday.
ai_summary: The Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit, available only with the IP Enhance option as indicated in the Policy Schedule, provides additional monthly payments (1/3rd of the Benefit Amount) to the Life Insured after 24 months of total claim eligibility, contingent upon achieving Maximum Medical Improvement, being entitled to the Totally Unable to Work Benefit, and meeting the criteria for Serious and Permanent Incapacity. This benefit is paid in addition to the Totally Unable to Work Benefit and ceases upon the Life Insured no longer meeting the incapacity criteria, reaching the end of the Benefit Period, or turning 65.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
• Sera has Income Protection IP Enhance with a monthly benefit of $7,500, with no Increasing Claim Option.
• Sera was involved in a motor vehicle accident and suffered spinal cord injury which resulted in paralysis from her waist down.
• After being on claim for 24 months, Sera remains Totally Unable to Work in Any Occupation and her paralysis is expected to be permanent.
• For the first 24 months of the Claim Period, Sera was paid the Totally Unable to Work Benefit at $7,500 per month. From the 25th month onwards, the Totally Unable to Work Benefit payable is:
2/3 X Benefit Amount
= 2/3 X $7,500
= $5,000 per month
• At the 25th month of claim, Sera meets the requirements for the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit because she remains Totally Unable to Work in Any Occupation, she has achieved Maximum Medical Improvement and she is Seriously and Permanently Incapacitated. The Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit payable is:
1/3 X Benefit Amount
= 1/3 X $7,500
= $2,500 per month
• The total monthly benefit payable to Sera from month 25 onwards is:
$5,000 + $2,500 = $7,500 per month
ai_summary: Sera holds an Income Protection policy with a monthly benefit of $7,500 and has been Totally Unable to Work following a motor vehicle accident that caused permanent paralysis. After 24 months of receiving the full benefit, her payment will adjust to $5,000 per month, with an additional $2,500 from the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit, resulting in a total of $7,500 monthly from the 25th month onward, as she meets the criteria for permanent incapacity.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: When will we adjust your benefit payments?
content:
Income Protection only covers loss of Earnings solely as a result of a Sickness or Injury. It does not cover losses due to economic circumstances. In certain circumstances, the Partially Unable to Work Benefit will be adjusted if loss of Earnings is not solely due to a Sickness or Injury. The Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable will be adjusted if:
• the Life Insured’s Earnings (when Partially Unable to Work) do not align to the amount of work being performed by the Life Insured (i.e. the Earnings are not commensurate with the work performed) for at least three consecutive months; and/or
• the Life Insured is not working to their full capability, including:
— the Life Insured is not working but capable of working for at least three consecutive months; or
— the Life Insured is working but not to their full capability for at least three consecutive months.
An adjustment to the Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable will be based on the Life Insured’s potential Earnings. The potential Earnings is the amount that the Life Insured could reasonably earn after taking into account their capability to work. When calculating the benefit payable, we will substitute Earnings with what we consider is the Life Insured’s potential Earnings.
The potential Earnings will take into consideration the Life Insured’s Earnings compared to the number of hours worked, and the Life Insured’s capability to work compared to their average weekly working hours in the 12 months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period. The average working hours immediately before the start of the Waiting Period will be limited to the lesser of:
• the Life Insured’s normal average weekly working hours (excluding overtime); or
• 40 hours a week.
If we adjust the benefit payment, we will act reasonably when determining the adjusted Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable.
Where we adjust the benefit payment under this clause, we will notify and explain our decision to you before we apply the adjustment.
The examples below are not real and should only be used to help you understand how we may apply an adjustment.
ai_summary: Income Protection benefits are solely for earnings lost due to Sickness or Injury, excluding economic losses. Adjustments to the Partially Unable to Work Benefit may occur if the Life Insured’s earnings do not reflect their work performed or if they are not working to full capability for at least three consecutive months. Adjustments will be based on the Life Insured’s potential earnings, considering their capability and average working hours prior to the Waiting Period, capped at 40 hours per week. The insurer will notify the policyholder of any adjustments made to the benefit payment, ensuring a reasonable determination process.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
• John regularly works 60 hours a week and earns an average of $15,000 per month before coming on claim.
• John has IP Focus option with a Benefit Amount of $10,000 per month.
• After receiving the Totally Unable to Work Benefit for six months, the Medical Practitioner certifies John as having the capacity to work 20 hours a week. John decides to work 10 hours a week.
• John’s full-time hours are calculated as the lesser of his pre-claim full-time hours (60) and 40 hours per week.
• John is capable of working 20 hours per week. He is deemed capable of earning 20/40 = 50% of his current full-time equivalent Earnings.
• John’s potential Earnings are calculated as:
$15,000 x 50% = $7,500 per month
• John’s adjusted Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable is:
Benefit Amount – 75% potential Earnings
= $10,000 – (75% x $7,500)
= $4,375 per month
ai_summary: John, who previously earned $15,000 monthly while working 60 hours a week, has an Income Protection (IP) policy with a benefit amount of $10,000 per month. After six months of receiving the Totally Unable to Work Benefit, he is certified to work 20 hours weekly but chooses to work 10 hours. His potential earnings are calculated at $7,500 (50% of his full-time equivalent earnings), leading to an adjusted Partially Unable to Work Benefit of $4,375 per month, determined by subtracting 75% of his potential earnings from his benefit amount.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Jane is a self-employed accountant. Prior to claim, Jane worked 32 hours a week and the business was earning an average of $10,000 a month (net profit).
Jane has IP Enhance option with a Benefit Amount of $7,000 per month.
While on claim, Jane is medically certified as fit to work 20 hours a week, performing all her work duties. However, Jane reports that her business is making a loss (for reasons other than a Sickness or Injury) despite working more than 50% of her pre-claim work hours.
Jane’s Earnings do not align to the amount of work she is performing. Her potential Earnings are calculated as:
20 hours / 32 hours x $10,000 = $6,250 per month
Jane’s adjusted Partially Unable to Work Benefit is:
Benefit Amount – 75% of potential Earnings
= $7,000 – (75% x $6,250)
= $2,312.50 per month
After 9 months Jane returns to work (32 hours per week). Her claim is finalised.
ai_summary: Jane, a self-employed accountant, has an Income Protection (IP) Enhance option with a benefit amount of $7,000 per month. Despite being medically certified to work 20 hours weekly, her business incurs losses unrelated to her health, leading to an adjusted Partially Unable to Work Benefit of $2,312.50 per month, calculated as the benefit amount minus 75% of her potential earnings of $6,250. After nine months, Jane resumes her full 32-hour workweek, concluding her claim.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
ai_summary: Benefits under the Income Protection policy cease under specific conditions: the Totally Unable to Work Benefit ends when the insured is no longer totally unable to work, their earnings surpass pre-claims earnings, the Benefit Period concludes, or the plan reaches its end date. Similarly, the Partially Unable to Work Benefit stops if the insured is no longer partially unable to work, if it is not payable for three consecutive months (with exceptions), at the end of the Benefit Period, or when the plan ends. For policies with a 'to age 65' Benefit Period, additional details are provided in Section 2.6.6.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: What happens if your claim was finalised but the condition reoccurs?
content:
If a claim has been paid under the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, we understand in certain circumstances the condition may reoccur from the same or a related cause during the term of the Plan. Where this happens within 12 months from the date the claim was last paid to, the reoccurrence will be considered a continuation of the initial claim. The Waiting Period will not be reapplied.
If the above applies, the Claim Period does not reset. All periods where the person qualifies for a Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit from any recurrent claims count towards the Claim Period and the Benefit Period.
ai_summary: If a claim under the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit is finalized and the condition recurs within 12 months, it will be treated as a continuation of the original claim, with no new Waiting Period applied. Additionally, the Claim Period remains unchanged, meaning all qualifying periods for recurrent claims contribute to the overall Claim Period and Benefit Period.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: What happens if your claim was finalised but the condition reoccurs?
content:
Example
• David has Income Protection with the IP Enhance option with a Benefit Amount of $7,500 per month (the Increasing Claim Option has not been selected by David so does not apply).
• David suffered a Sickness or Injury and was medically certified Totally Unable to Work in his Own Occupation.
• David was paid the Totally Unable to Work Benefit for 19 months before he returned to full time work (total Claim Period of 19 months) and his claim was finalised. The Benefit Amount for this Claim Period is $7,500 per month.
• Two months after returning to full-time work, the condition which he previously claimed under reoccurred and David had to stop work again completely.
• David’s claim was restarted, and benefits became payable from the day he ceased work because of the same condition. The Waiting Period did not apply due to the reoccurrence of the same claim condition within 12 months.
• David had to remain on claim for another nine months before returning to full time work again.
• For the first five of the nine months, the monthly benefit payable will be calculated based on $7,500 (the Benefit Amount). The total Claim Period is 19 + 5 = 24 months.
• From the 25th month onwards, the benefit payable will be calculated based on 2/3rd of the Benefit Amount. For the remaining four months, the monthly benefit payable will be calculated based on:
2/3 X Benefit Amount
= 2/3 X $7,500
= $5,000 per month
ai_summary: If a claimant, like David, who has Income Protection with a Benefit Amount of $7,500 per month, experiences a recurrence of the same condition within 12 months of returning to work, their claim can be restarted without a waiting period. David initially received benefits for 19 months, and upon reoccurrence, he received an additional five months of benefits at the full amount, followed by four months at two-thirds of the Benefit Amount, totaling 24 months of coverage.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: What happens if another Sickness or Injury occurs while you are already on claim?
content:
If the Life Insured becomes Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work because of separate and distinct Sicknesses or Injuries during the same period, only one benefit will be payable and only one Claim Period will apply. The Life Insured will be eligible for benefit payments from the end of the Waiting Period relating to the first Sickness or Injury and the Claim Period starts from the end of the Waiting Period relating to the first Sickness or Injury.
For 1 year, 2 year and 5 year Benefit Periods, once the maximum Benefit Period has been reached, you will not be able to make another claim for the same or related Sickness or Injury. If you make another claim for a distinct and separate Sickness or Injury, you must have returned to work for at least six consecutive months, working at least 20 hours per week on average.
ai_summary: If the Life Insured becomes Totally or Partially Unable to Work due to separate Sicknesses or Injuries while on claim, only one benefit will be paid, and the Claim Period will commence after the Waiting Period of the first condition. For Benefit Periods of 1, 2, or 5 years, once the maximum Benefit Period is reached, no further claims can be made for the same or related conditions; a new claim for a distinct condition requires the Life Insured to have returned to work for at least six consecutive months, averaging 20 hours per week.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: What happens if another Sickness or Injury occurs while you are already on claim?
content:
Example
• Jill has IP Focus option with a 2 year Benefit Period.
• Jill suffered a Sickness and was medically certified Totally Unable to Work in her Own Occupation.
• While she was on claim, she suffered an Injury which also prevented her from working. Immediately before the Injury, Jill had already received 20 months of Totally Unable to Work Benefit due to her Sickness. An additional benefit will not be paid for Jill’s Injury while she is already on claim.
• Jill remained Totally Unable to Work due to both the Sickness and Injury for another six months. However, her claim will be finalised once her Claim Period has reached 24 months because Jill selected to have a 2 year Benefit Period.
• For Jill to be eligible to make another claim on her Income Protection, she must return to work for at least 6 consecutive months, working at least 20 hours per week on average. Jill will not be able to make another claim for the same Sickness/Injury or related Sickness/Injury for which the maximum Benefit Period has already been paid for.
ai_summary: If a policyholder, like Jill, is already receiving Income Protection benefits and subsequently suffers another Sickness or Injury, no additional benefits will be paid while on claim, even if the new condition extends their inability to work. Jill's claim will conclude once the maximum Benefit Period of 24 months is reached, and to be eligible for a new claim, she must return to work for at least 6 consecutive months, averaging 20 hours per week, without being able to claim for the same or related conditions that have already exhausted the Benefit Period.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Inflation Protection Benefit
We will increase the Benefit Amount (and the Super Contribution Benefit Amount if applicable) by the Indexation Factor at each Policy anniversary.
This increase will occur on each Policy anniversary unless:
• you tell us the Inflation Protection Benefit is not to apply to your Plan;
• premiums are being waived under the Waiver of Premium Benefit; or
• cover is suspended under the Premium Pause Benefit.
ai_summary: The Inflation Protection Benefit ensures that the Benefit Amount and, if applicable, the Super Contribution Benefit Amount are increased annually by the Indexation Factor at each Policy anniversary. However, this increase will not apply if the policyholder opts out, if premiums are waived under the Waiver of Premium Benefit, or if coverage is suspended under the Premium Pause Benefit.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
The Bed Confinement Benefit is payable when the Life Insured is:
• Bed Confined during the Waiting Period for at least 72 consecutive hours; and
• Totally Unable to Work.
The amount payable will be 1/30th of the Benefit Amount for each day of Bed Confinement, less any other payments (refer to Section 2.6.5).
The Bed Confinement Benefit is paid monthly in arrears.
The Bed Confinement Benefit will stop on the earlier of the following event:
• the Life Insured is no longer Bed Confined;
• the Life Insured is no longer Totally Unable to Work;
• the end of the Waiting Period;
• the Plan end date; or
• the payments equalling 28 days having occurred.
ai_summary: The Bed Confinement Benefit provides financial support to the Life Insured who is bed confined for at least 72 consecutive hours and is totally unable to work during the Waiting Period. The benefit amount is calculated as 1/30th of the total Benefit Amount for each day of confinement, paid monthly in arrears, and ceases upon the Life Insured no longer being bed confined or unable to work, the end of the Waiting Period, the Plan end date, or after 28 days of payments.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
The Waiver of Premium Benefit applies when the Totally Unable to Work Benefit and/or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit are payable. If the Waiver of Premium Benefit applies, the daily proportion of premiums due in respect of the Life Insured under Income Protection will be waived.
The Waiver of Premium Benefit:
• starts to accrue from the first day of the Waiting Period; and
• applies immediately after the Waiting Period for any premiums paid during the Waiting Period and monthly in arrears for subsequent premiums.
The Waiver of Premium Benefit will stop on the earlier of:
• the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit are no longer payable; or
• the end of the Benefit Period.
ai_summary: The Waiver of Premium Benefit is activated when the Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work Benefits are being paid, waiving the daily proportion of premiums for the Life Insured under Income Protection. This benefit begins accruing from the first day of the Waiting Period, covering premiums paid during that time and continuing monthly thereafter, ceasing when either work-related benefit is no longer payable or at the end of the Benefit Period.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
For 1 year, 2 year and 5 year Benefit Periods, this will mean premium payments will recommence once you have reached the end of the Benefit Period for any one condition or related condition, even if you are still Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work.
If Superlink IP applies, the Waiver Of Premium Benefit will apply to both Income Protection Policies.
Not available when Income Protection is structured through superannuation.
The Work Assistance Benefit reimburses the cost of an approved Rehabilitation Program that assists in the effective rehabilitation of the Life Insured to return to work, less amounts reimbursed from elsewhere. Payment of Work Assistance Benefit is subject to:
• our approval of the expenditure; and
• a maximum allowable reimbursement of 12 times the Benefit Amount at the start of the Waiting Period.
The cost of medication, medical consultations or medical therapy consultations, including but not limited to, physiotherapy, psychotherapy and hydrotherapy, are not covered under the Work Assistance Benefit.
This benefit will only be paid once across all Income Protection Plans issued by us for each claim event or concurrent claim.
ai_summary: The Work Assistance Benefit under the Income Protection policy reimburses costs for an approved Rehabilitation Program to help the insured return to work, up to a maximum of 12 times the Benefit Amount at the start of the Waiting Period, subject to prior approval. Premium payments will resume after the Benefit Period ends, regardless of the insured's work status, and this benefit is not available for policies structured through superannuation. Additionally, it does not cover expenses related to medication or medical consultations, and it is limited to one payment per claim event across all issued Income Protection Plans.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If the Life Insured dies, we will pay $10,000. If you receive any death benefits from other income protection cover with TAL, these amounts will reduce the death benefit paid under this Policy.
This benefit will not be paid if the death arises directly or indirectly as a result of an intentional, self-inflicted act by the Life Insured:
• within 13 months after the Plan start date;
• within 13 months after the date of any increases applied for, but only in respect of the increase amount; or
• within 13 months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate the Plan or Policy.
ai_summary: In the event of the Life Insured's death, a benefit of $10,000 will be paid, subject to reductions if other death benefits from TAL's income protection cover are received. This benefit is excluded if the death results from intentional self-inflicted acts within 13 months of the Plan start date, any recent increases, or reinstatement of the Policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Not available when Income Protection is structured through superannuation.
If the Life Insured is outside Australia and qualifies for the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit, we will pay for the cost for the Life Insured to return to Australia.
ai_summary: The Overseas Assistance Benefit under the Income Protection policy is not applicable if the coverage is structured through superannuation. However, if the Life Insured is outside Australia and qualifies for either the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit, the insurer will cover the costs for their return to Australia.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
The amount paid will be a reimbursement of the costs directly incurred by the Life Insured in returning to Australia, less amounts reimbursed from elsewhere, to a maximum of three times the Benefit Amount for any one claim. The amount we reimburse excludes the cost of any premier, business or first class seat.
This benefit will only be paid once across all Income Protection Plans issued by us for each claim event or concurrent claim.
ai_summary: The Overseas Assistance Benefit under the Income Protection policy reimburses the Life Insured for costs incurred in returning to Australia, up to a maximum of three times the Benefit Amount per claim, excluding any premier, business, or first-class seat costs. This benefit is limited to one payment per claim event or concurrent claim across all Income Protection Plans issued by the insurer.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
You may apply to temporarily suspend paying Income Protection premiums and cover for up to 12 months. The following conditions apply to the Premium Pause Benefit:
• It only applies if Income Protection premiums have been paid for at least 12 consecutive months immediately prior to applying for the Premium Pause Benefit.
• You must provide us with evidence which establishes (in our reasonable opinion), that the Life Insured has stopped working due to Unemployment or Long Term Leave.
• No premiums are due, no Benefit Amount is payable, and no indexation occurs, while premium suspension continues.
• No benefit is payable for any Sickness or Injury (whichever is applicable) that occurs while Income Protection is suspended or during the 90 days following the end of the Premium Pause Benefit.
• It does not apply to any period where premiums have already been paid.
• We will not require evidence of the Life Insured’s health, occupation, income or pastimes, or any other Underwriting information if premium payments for Income Protection restart before the end of the 12 months from when premiums were suspended.
• You must contact us to recommence cover and restart premium payments. If premiums are not restarted within 12 months from the start of the Premium Pause Benefit, the option to recommence cover will no longer be available and the Plan will be cancelled.
ai_summary: The Premium Pause Benefit allows you to temporarily suspend Income Protection premiums and coverage for up to 12 months, provided premiums have been paid for at least 12 consecutive months prior. To qualify, you must demonstrate that the Life Insured has ceased working due to Unemployment or Long Term Leave. During the suspension, no premiums are due, no benefits are payable, and no indexation occurs; additionally, no benefits will be provided for any Sickness or Injury occurring during the suspension or within 90 days after. To resume coverage and premium payments, you must contact the insurer within the 12-month period; failure to do so will result in cancellation of the plan.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Under the Elective Surgery Benefit, the following will be considered a Sickness for the purpose of assessing entitlement to the Totally Unable to Work Benefit:
• the Life Insured undergoes surgery to transplant part of the Life Insured’s body to someone else;
• the Life Insured undergoes surgery to improve the Life Insured’s appearance; or
• the Life Insured undergoes elective surgery performed on the advice of a medical practitioner.
The Elective Surgery Benefit will not apply if the surgery took place:
• within six months after the Plan start date;
• within six months after the date of any increase applied for, but only in respect of the increase amount; or
• within six months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate the Plan.
Where Income Protection is structured through superannuation (as indicated in the Policy Schedule), the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS legislation and rules.
ai_summary: The Elective Surgery Benefit under the Income Protection policy allows for certain surgeries to be classified as a Sickness when assessing eligibility for the Totally Unable to Work Benefit, including surgeries for organ donation, cosmetic improvements, or elective procedures advised by a medical practitioner. However, this benefit is not applicable if the surgery occurs within six months of the Plan's start date, any increase in coverage, or the most recent reinstatement date. Additionally, if the Income Protection is structured through superannuation, compliance with SIS legislation is required.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If the Life Insured is a health care professional, for example a medical doctor, surgeon or dentist, and they contract a blood borne disease such as HIV, Hepatitis B or C, their ability to work can be affected by factors other than physical inability due to the illness. The following is our approach to claims. There are three scenarios that could affect the Life Insured. For all three scenarios the Life Insured must notify the relevant governing body of their medical condition:
• the Life Insured chooses to disclose their condition to their patients which may lead to some of their patients seeking medical treatment elsewhere. It could also be difficult for the Life Insured to attract new patients;
• the Life Insured chooses to cease performing Exposure Prone Procedures as defined by the relevant governing body; or
• the Life Insured’s governing body advises the Life Insured to cease performing Exposure Prone Procedures as defined by the relevant governing body.
In all of these scenarios it is likely that the Life Insured’s income will reduce. In all these cases we will assess whether the Life Insured is Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work in accordance with the terms and conditions of their Policy. If the ‘to age 65’ Benefit Period applies, the Blood Borne Disease Benefit will cease when the Claim Period reaches 24 months. Where Income Protection is structured through superannuation (as indicated in the Policy Schedule), the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS legislation and rules.
ai_summary: The Blood Borne Diseases Benefit under Income Protection applies to health care professionals who contract diseases like HIV or Hepatitis B/C, potentially impacting their ability to work due to factors beyond physical illness. The Life Insured must notify their governing body and may experience reduced income if they disclose their condition to patients, cease performing Exposure Prone Procedures, or are advised to stop such procedures. Claims will assess whether the Life Insured is Totally or Partially Unable to Work, with the benefit ceasing after 24 months if the 'to age 65' Benefit Period applies. Additionally, if Income Protection is through superannuation, compliance with SIS legislation is required.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: The options listed below only apply if indicated in your Policy Schedule.
ai_summary: Section 2.6.3 outlines optional benefits for Income Protection that are applicable only if specified in the Policy Schedule. These benefits may enhance coverage but require explicit inclusion in the policy documentation to be effective.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: If the Increasing Claim Option applies, the Benefit Amount will increase by the Indexation Factor on each anniversary when the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit first became payable. The Increasing Claim Option also applies to the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit and the Super Contribution Option (if applicable).
ai_summary: The Increasing Claim Option allows the Benefit Amount to rise annually by the Indexation Factor, starting from the first payment of either the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit. This option also extends to the Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit and the Super Contribution Option, if applicable.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: If the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit is payable, we will make a superannuation contribution on your behalf, which will be paid directly to the superannuation fund nominated by you.
ai_summary: In the event that the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit is activated, the insurer will contribute to your nominated superannuation fund on your behalf, ensuring continued financial support during your period of inability to work.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
The amount payable each month will be Where
A is the lesser of the following:
• the Super Contribution Benefit Amount;
• the average Employer Superannuation Contribution amount in the 12 months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period; and
• 15% of your monthly Pre-Claim Earnings.

A ÷ B × C
B is the Benefit Amount (Income Protection) at the start of the Waiting Period, plus increases under the Increasing Claim Option, if applicable.

C is the:
• Totally Unable to Work Benefit plus Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit (if applicable) payable; or
• Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable.
In calculating C, any offsets listed in Section 2.6.5 will not apply.
ai_summary: The monthly payment for the Income Protection Super Contribution Option is determined by the lesser of the Super Contribution Benefit Amount, the average Employer Superannuation Contribution from the previous 12 months, or 15% of the monthly Pre-Claim Earnings. The payment calculation uses the formula A ÷ B × C, where A is the determined amount, B is the Income Protection Benefit Amount at the start of the Waiting Period (including any applicable increases), and C is either the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, excluding any offsets specified in Section 2.6.5.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: The Super Contribution Option benefit payable will be paid on your behalf as a personal contribution to a superannuation fund nominated by you. The Super Contribution Option benefit can only be paid to an eligible complying superannuation fund and is subject to the standard superannuation rules relating to contributions, taxation and preservation. Your nominated fund may also have rules (or restrictions) on certain contribution types. Before nominating your fund for receipt of the Super Contribution Option benefit, you should check with your nominated fund that the fund rules permit receipt of the Super Contribution Option benefit. The Super Contribution Option benefit should generally constitute assessable income and therefore you should keep a record of any Super Contribution Option benefit paid, to enable you to prepare your individual tax return. If you satisfy the tests for claiming a tax deduction in respect of the personal contributions and give the trustee of the nominated superannuation fund a valid notice of intent that is acknowledged, you may be entitled to a tax deduction in respect of some or all of the personal contributions. If you provide the trustee of the nominated superannuation fund with a valid notice that you intend to claim a tax deduction for the personal contributions, then the trustee should treat the contributions as concessional contributions which are generally subject to tax at 15% in the superannuation fund and this tax may be deducted from your account depending on the trustee’s policy. There may be different tax treatment of your Super Contribution Option benefit and taxation issues that arise depending on whether you structure your Policy through superannuation. These matters are your responsibility, and you may wish to seek financial and tax advice. In order to receive this benefit, you must provide us with your instructions and any necessary information we request to make the personal contribution on your behalf. Benefits paid under the Super Contribution Option may impact your tax status and/or your superannuation contribution cap. Refer to Section 7 for more information on tax. Where the trustee of a self-managed superannuation fund (SMSF) is the Policy Owner of the Income Protection Policy, the Super Contribution Option benefit can only be paid to the trustee of that SMSF and cannot be paid to a different nominated fund. The trustee of the SMSF is responsible for complying with superannuation and taxation legislation in respect of receiving the Super Contribution Option benefit. Where Income Protection is structured through superannuation, the SIS legislation and rules must also be satisfied.
ai_summary: The Super Contribution Option allows for benefits to be paid as personal contributions to a nominated complying superannuation fund, subject to standard superannuation rules and the fund's specific regulations. Recipients must verify their fund's acceptance of these contributions and maintain records for tax purposes, as the benefit generally constitutes assessable income. If eligible, individuals may claim a tax deduction for personal contributions, which could be treated as concessional contributions subject to a 15% tax within the fund. Compliance with superannuation and taxation legislation is essential, especially for self-managed superannuation funds (SMSFs), and individuals should seek financial advice regarding potential impacts on their tax status and contribution caps.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Payment of the Super Contribution Option:
• will start when the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit is payable; and
• is paid monthly in arrears.
ai_summary: The Super Contribution Option payments commence when either the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit is activated, and these payments are disbursed monthly in arrears.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
