Payments under the Super Contribution Option will stop on the earlier of the following events:
• the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit is no longer payable; or
• the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 60th birthday.
ai_summary: Under the Super Contribution Option of the Income Protection policy, payments will cease upon the earlier occurrence of either the termination of the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit, or at the policy anniversary preceding the Life Insured's 60th birthday.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Phil is an Employee who has elected the IP Enhance income replacement option and the Super Contribution Option. Phil is the owner of the Income Protection Policy. The Increasing Claim Option has not been selected by Phil so does not apply.
Phil has an insured monthly benefit of $7,000 per month and a Super Contribution Benefit Amount of $1,000 per month.
Phil suffers a Sickness and satisfies the requirements of the Totally Unable to Work Benefit.
Phil's Pre-Claim Earnings are $10,000 per month. His average Employer Superannuation Contribution amount in the 12 months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period was $1,000 per month.
Phil's initial Super Contribution Benefit Amount is $1,000 per month (=A).
Phil's initial Benefit Amount is $7,000 per month (=B).
Phil remains Totally Unable to Work for 36 months.
- During the first 24 months, Phil receives a Totally Unable to Work Benefit of $7,000 per month (=C).
The amount paid under the Super Contribution Option is:
A ÷ B x C = $1,000 ÷ $7,000 x $7,000 = $1,000 per month
- From the 25th month onwards, Phil receives a Totally Unable to Work Benefit of $7,000 per month x 2/3 = $4,666.67 (=C). The amount paid under the Super Contribution Option is:
A ÷ B x C = $1,000 ÷ $7,000 x $4,666.67 = $666.67 per month
ai_summary: Phil, an employee with an Income Protection Policy, has chosen the IP Enhance income replacement option and a Super Contribution Option, receiving an insured monthly benefit of $7,000 and a Super Contribution Benefit of $1,000. After becoming Totally Unable to Work due to sickness, he receives $7,000 per month for the first 24 months, with the Super Contribution amount remaining at $1,000. From the 25th month, his benefit decreases to $4,666.67, resulting in a reduced Super Contribution of $666.67 per month, reflecting the policy's terms and conditions.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
ai_summary: Superlink IP enables the linking of an Income Protection Policy outside superannuation with one structured through superannuation, resulting in two policies issued: one to the superannuation fund trustee and the other to the Life Insured. Key conditions include that both policies must maintain identical terms regarding benefit amounts and waiting periods, and any changes to one policy will simultaneously affect the other. Cancellation of either policy will impact the other unless prior written notification is provided. Benefits will be paid from the superannuation policy if SIS rules are met; otherwise, payments will come from the policy outside superannuation. The total benefits from both policies cannot exceed what would be payable under a single policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
ai_summary: Income Protection benefits will not be paid if the claim results from intentional self-harm, normal pregnancy-related conditions, war-related incidents, participation in criminal activities, or any restrictions on the Life Insured's ability to perform their occupation due to legal or regulatory actions.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If Life Insured is outside Australia, the Totally Unable To Work Benefit and/or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit will be limited to three months of payments. Entitlement to further and/or ongoing benefits will be assessed once the Life Insured returns to Australia and has met the necessary claim requirements (refer to Section 3 for details).
If we limit payment of the Totally Unable to Work Benefit and/or Partially Unable to Work Benefit payment to three months and the Life Insured remains Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work, the Overseas Assistance Benefit may be available to assist the Life Insured to return to Australia.
This limitation will not apply during periods when the Life Insured is medically certified as unfit for air travel, or where air travel to Australia is not possible.
ai_summary: When the Life Insured is outside Australia, the Totally Unable To Work and Partially Unable to Work Benefits are capped at three months, with further benefits contingent upon the Life Insured's return and fulfillment of claim requirements. If the Life Insured remains unable to work after this period, the Overseas Assistance Benefit may be available to facilitate their return to Australia, except during times when they are medically unfit for air travel or when travel is not feasible.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: 2.6.5 When we will reduce the benefit payment if an offset applies
content:
How we will calculate your benefit when an offset applies
If an offset applies, the net amount payable for a claim will be calculated as follows (as applicable):
• Totally Unable to Work Benefit plus Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit (if applicable), less ‘other payments’, less ‘Earnings while Totally Unable to Work’;
• Partially Unable to Work Benefit less ‘other payments’; or
• Bed Confinement Benefit, less ‘other payments’, less ‘Earnings while Totally Unable to Work’.
The types of offsets ‘Earnings while Totally Unable to Work’ and ‘Other payments’ are described below.
ai_summary: In the event that an offset applies, the benefit payment for a claim will be calculated by deducting 'other payments' and 'Earnings while Totally Unable to Work' from the applicable benefit type: either the Totally Unable to Work Benefit plus any Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit, the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, or the Bed Confinement Benefit. Detailed definitions of 'Earnings while Totally Unable to Work' and 'other payments' are provided in the document.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Earnings while Totally Unable to Work
content:
We will reduce the Totally Unable to Work Benefit, Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit and Bed Confinement Benefit if the Life Insured:
• receives any Earnings, or
• is entitled to any Earnings when the Life Insured is Self-Employed,
while the Totally Unable to Work Benefit is payable.
ai_summary: The Totally Unable to Work Benefit, Permanent Incapacity Reset Benefit, and Bed Confinement Benefit will be reduced if the Life Insured receives or is entitled to any Earnings while the Totally Unable to Work Benefit is being paid, particularly for those who are Self-Employed.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
ai_summary: The benefits under the Income Protection Plan, including the Totally Unable to Work Benefit and others, will be reduced if the Life Insured receives payments from undisclosed disability insurance, workers’ compensation, or other employment-related payments that do not account for this plan. Exclusions from this offset include one-time retention payments and investment returns from employment.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: If any of the other payments above are received as a lump sum, we will only reduce what we pay to you by the portion of the lump sum relating to loss of income, loss of earning capacity or any other economic loss, for the corresponding period you were entitled to the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or Partially Unable to Work Benefit. The lump sum amount will be converted to a monthly amount based on 1% of the lump sum per month. The disability payment will be calculated taking this figure into account for a maximum of eight years. You must provide to us the breakdown of the lump sum received as soon as reasonably practicable. This should include the portions of the lump sum relating to loss of income, loss of earning capacity or any other economic loss and any other information we reasonably require. Where you do not provide enough information for us to identify the portions of the lump sum relating to loss of income, loss of earning capacity or any other economic loss, we will, acting reasonably, determine the portions of the lump sum amount relating to or referrable to loss of income, loss of earning capacity or any other economic loss for the purpose of calculating the offset amount.
ai_summary: In the event of receiving a lump sum payment, your income protection benefits will be reduced only by the portion related to loss of income or earning capacity for the duration of the Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work Benefits. This portion will be converted to a monthly amount at 1% of the lump sum, affecting disability payments for up to eight years. You must provide a detailed breakdown of the lump sum, including relevant portions, promptly; otherwise, the insurer will estimate these amounts reasonably for offset calculations.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: When structured through a retail superannuation fund, Income Protection will end when you cease to be a member of the retail superannuation fund. This means that your Policy will be cancelled from the date you cease to be a member of the retail superannuation fund. You can apply within 60 days of the date your Policy was cancelled to continue the Plan with no further medical or financial requirement. Any special conditions or loadings which applied to the original Plan will also apply to the new Plan.
ai_summary: Income Protection coverage through a retail superannuation fund terminates upon ceasing membership, resulting in policy cancellation. However, individuals can apply within 60 days of cancellation to continue their Plan without additional medical or financial assessments, retaining any special conditions or loadings from the original Plan.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
ai_summary: Income Protection benefits will cease under these Plans upon the earliest occurrence of the following: receipt of a written cancellation request from the Policy Owner or insured, cancellation due to non-payment of premiums, the policy anniversary prior to the Life Insured’s 65th birthday, cancellation due to misrepresentation or fraudulent claims, or the death of the Life Insured.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If your Plan has a ‘to age 65’ Benefit Period and you were Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work immediately before the Plan end date as stated in the Policy Schedule, we will assess your claim until the earlier of the following:
• the Life Insured is no longer Totally Unable to Work or no longer Partially Unable to Work;
• the Life Insured’s 65th birthday; or
• the death of the Life Insured.
ai_summary: Income Protection benefits will continue until the earliest of the Life Insured's recovery from Total or Partial inability to work, their 65th birthday, or their death, provided the Plan includes a 'to age 65' Benefit Period and the Life Insured was unable to work immediately before the Plan's end date.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Page contains a large photograph of two people, one laughing, holding coffee cups. There is no PDS-related text content on this page.
ai_summary: The page features a photograph of two individuals enjoying coffee, with no textual content related to the Product Disclosure Statement (PDS) or specific details regarding the termination of Income Protection coverage. Therefore, no key information, benefits, conditions, or requirements are provided in this section.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
We will support you through the process of making a claim. If you wish to make a claim against the Policy, we strongly encourage you to contact us at the earliest possible opportunity. If you don’t tell us about the life Insured’s sickness or injury when it happens, and this affects our ability to gather evidence that we require to assess your claim, then this may potentially impact the time that it will take us to assess your claim.

Our contact details can be found on the back cover of this PDS. When we are notified that you wish to make a claim, we will provide the forms that need to be completed and explain in detail our requirements and what the next steps are.
ai_summary: To initiate a claim under the Policy, it is crucial to notify us as soon as possible about the life Insured's sickness or injury, as delays may hinder our ability to gather necessary evidence and impact claim assessment timelines. Upon notification, we will provide the required forms and detailed instructions for the next steps in the claims process.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
ai_summary: To successfully file a claim, the event must occur while your insurance coverage is active, and payments can only be made during this period. Claims will be assessed based on compliance with policy terms, including any special conditions, and may require documentation such as a completed claim form, signed authorization for information collection, proof of the event, and, in death claims, proof of probate and a death certificate. Additionally, information regarding prior medical, employment, and lifestyle history may be necessary to ensure no misrepresentation occurred during the policy application process. All requested information must be provided to validate the claim and determine the insurer's ongoing liability.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
While we assess your claim and unless we tell you otherwise, it is important to continue to pay premiums to ensure your cover is not cancelled.

If you are experiencing financial hardship, please call us on 1300 209 088 to discuss options that may be available to help you. You may also need to provide supporting documentation to assist with your financial hardship application. Alternatively, you can discuss this with your financial adviser.
ai_summary: To maintain your insurance coverage while your claim is being assessed, it is essential to continue paying your premiums unless instructed otherwise. If you face financial hardship, contact us at 1300 209 088 to explore available assistance options, which may require supporting documentation, or consult your financial adviser for guidance.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
For the purpose of:
• Critical Illness Insurance Death Buy-Back Benefit;
• Critical Illness Insurance Reinstatement Option; or
• TPD Insurance Death Buy-Back Option,

formal claim notification requirements consist of enough details of the claim to enable our assessment of the claim to commence including the Policy number, the condition claimed for and the date of the event or diagnosis.
ai_summary: Formal claim notification for Critical Illness Insurance Death Buy-Back Benefit, Reinstatement Option, or TPD Insurance Death Buy-Back Option must include essential details such as the Policy number, the specific condition being claimed, and the date of the event or diagnosis to initiate the assessment process.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
ai_summary: To validate a claim, we require evidence of our liability to pay benefits, which may include a medical examination by a designated Medical Practitioner, specialist assessments, and proof of the medical necessity of surgical procedures. Claimants must submit initial medical reports and certificates from qualified Medical Practitioners to certify the claimed condition. For Terminal Illness Benefit claims, certification from two treating Medical Practitioners is necessary, including one from a specialist, and the assessment will involve reviewing relevant medical treatment information.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
We may recalculate the amount of the Income Protection benefit that we would have otherwise paid if your Earnings were averaged over the relevant claim period, and either:
• pay any underpayment of Income Protection Benefit(s);
• recover any overpaid Income Protection Benefit(s); or
• reduce the amount of any future Income Protection Benefits(s) payable until the excess amount paid has been recovered.
If required, the trustee will deduct any tax payable from any benefit payment made from the fund.
ai_summary: In the event of a claim, the insurer may recalculate the Income Protection benefit based on averaged Earnings over the claim period, leading to potential adjustments such as paying any underpaid benefits, recovering overpayments, or reducing future benefit payments until excess amounts are recouped. Additionally, any applicable taxes will be deducted from benefit payments made from the fund.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
For Income Protection and TPD Insurance we may require:
• verification of the Life Insured’s Earnings stated in the application;
• verification of the Life Insured’s Earnings the period before and after the event giving rise to your claim; and/or
• an audit of the Life Insured’s business and personal financial circumstances as often as is required. This may include auditing documents that constitute a legal requirement such as business and personal taxation returns and profit and loss statements.
We will require you to provide us with copies of the tax returns lodged with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) or other financial documentation which verifies your Pre-Claim Earnings and your Earnings during the period for which we have paid an Income Protection benefit. We must receive this information by any reasonable time frame we require.
ai_summary: For Income Protection and Total Permanent Disability (TPD) Insurance claims, verification of the Life Insured's earnings is essential, including documentation of earnings before and after the claim event. Insurers may conduct audits of the Life Insured's financial circumstances, requiring copies of tax returns and other financial documents to confirm Pre-Claim Earnings and earnings during the benefit period, which must be provided within a specified timeframe.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
For Income Protection and TPD Insurance, you will be advised if you are required to provide verification of your occupation, including the breakdown of all the duties that you performed prior to ceasing work as a result of Sickness or Injury. If you are self-employed, your occupation will also take into consideration the duties required in running your business or a similar business. This information will be used to assess your ability to perform your occupation.
You and the Life Insured (if applicable) may be required to attend interviews by a member of our staff or someone appointed by us as often as is required to fully consider your claim.
We may also require:
• access to details of the Life Insured’s previous medical consultations;
• assessment of current functional and vocational capacity by an appropriately qualified person selected by us; or
• information from various parties, including you and the Life Insured (if applicable), in relation to your claim, by a member of our staff or someone appointed by us, as often as is required. This may include, but not be limited to, details of any previous Injury or Sickness claims in relation to the Life Insured and details of previous occupation duties.
We reserve the right to require any information or documents not listed above but which are reasonably necessary to the assessment of your claim and establishing our liability to pay a benefit under the Policy.
ai_summary: For Income Protection and TPD Insurance claims, verification of your occupation and a detailed breakdown of duties performed before ceasing work due to Sickness or Injury may be required. Self-employed individuals must also include business-related duties. The insurer may conduct interviews and request access to medical records, current functional assessments, and information from various parties to evaluate the claim. Additional documentation may be required as deemed necessary for assessing the claim and establishing liability for benefits under the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Meeting the costs of claim requirements
content: Where we request an examination or assessment by a person we nominate, we will pay the cost for this service. You will be responsible for other costs which may be incurred for example, having your claim forms completed by your attending doctor, and providing financial information as required (e.g. the cost of completing tax returns, profit and loss statements).
ai_summary: In the event that an examination or assessment is required by a nominated individual, the insurer will cover the associated costs. However, the claimant is responsible for any additional expenses incurred, such as fees for completing claim forms by their attending physician and providing necessary financial documentation, including tax returns and profit and loss statements.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
To obtain all relevant evidence to assess your claim and our liability under the Policy, we will require you or the Life Insured to provide us with written authority to receive information relevant to the assessment of the claim from third parties. For example, we may use this authority to seek information from medical practitioners who have treated you, including historical medical records which are relevant to determining whether the duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation was complied with when you applied for, reinstated or changed your Policy or Plan.
If you choose to withhold your consent and do not complete your authority, we may not be able to process your claim and your claim will be declined until we are able to obtain the information and evidence we reasonably require.
ai_summary: To assess your claim and determine our liability under the Policy, you or the Life Insured must provide written authority for us to obtain relevant information from third parties, such as medical practitioners. If you withhold consent, we may be unable to process your claim, potentially resulting in a decline until we acquire the necessary evidence to evaluate your claim effectively.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Claim payments are dependent on the Life Insured being or having been under the care and following or having followed the reasonable advice of a Medical Practitioner and an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner (where applicable). Following the advice of a Medical Practitioner or an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner includes:
• following the treatment advice and actively engaging in the treatment plan developed by a Medical Practitioner, including any health and return to work plan, medication, specialist intervention and therapies; and
• following and actively participating in an accredited Rehabilitation Program or return to work program, where appropriate.
If there is no improvement of the Life Insured’s symptoms where an improvement is generally expected in a person suffering from a similar condition, we may require:
• an assessment and confirmation of the diagnosis and severity of the signs and symptoms of the Life Insured’s medical condition and treatment plan by an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner; and
• where appropriate, that the Life Insured be under the care of an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner after considering the opinion of the treating Medical Practitioner and other medical information.
Benefit payments under Income Protection may be withheld if the Life Insured:
• is not following the advice or treatment plan as prescribed by the Medical Practitioner; or
• is not under the care of an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner, where appropriate.
ai_summary: Claim payments are contingent upon the Life Insured adhering to the treatment and rehabilitation plans prescribed by a Medical Practitioner and, when necessary, a specialist. This includes actively participating in treatment, medication, and accredited rehabilitation programs. If no improvement is observed in the Life Insured’s condition, further assessment by a specialist may be required. Benefit payments under Income Protection may be withheld if the Life Insured fails to follow the prescribed treatment or is not under the care of an appropriate specialist.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: 3.5 Obsolete criteria due to medical advancement
content: If the method for diagnosing the specified medical condition has been superseded by a revised clinical protocol, and the appropriate Australian medical body has recognised this revised criteria for diagnostic practice, we will apply the revised clinical protocol subject to our verification that the specified medical condition is conclusively diagnosed and to at least the same severity.
ai_summary: In the event that a diagnostic method for a specified medical condition is updated by a recognized Australian medical body, the insurance will adopt the new clinical protocol, provided that the condition is conclusively diagnosed and meets or exceeds the severity of the original criteria. This ensures that claims are assessed based on the most current medical standards.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: If you make a fraudulent claim under your Policy or another policy you have with us, then we may cancel your Policy.
ai_summary: Section 3.7 of the insurance document states that if you submit a fraudulent claim under your Policy or any other policy with the insurer, your Policy may be canceled. This highlights the importance of honesty in claims to maintain coverage.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: 3.8 Your obligation regarding disability duration and severity
content:
If we have provided you with a Policy, we have contracted to insure the Life Insured on the basis of the agreed cover. While we have accepted the risks associated with any potential loss, you and the Life Insured also have an obligation to mitigate your loss. You and the Life Insured must not knowingly contribute to the severity or longevity of the Life Insured’s disablement or your claim may not be accepted.
We may reduce or decline to pay benefits where the condition resulting in a claim is caused or contributed to by your failure to seek and follow medical advice or treatment. We may waive this requirement if, in the opinion of the Medical Practitioner, continued or future treatment would be of no benefit.
ai_summary: In this section, it is emphasized that both the policyholder and the Life Insured must actively mitigate any loss related to a disability claim. If either party knowingly exacerbates the severity or duration of the disability, the claim may be denied or benefits reduced. Additionally, failure to seek or adhere to medical advice can impact the claim's acceptance, although this requirement may be waived if a Medical Practitioner determines that further treatment would be ineffective.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: 3.10 When we will not pay a claim
ai_summary: Claims may be denied or benefits reduced if they relate to exclusions in the Policy Schedule or if Accelerated Protection is claimed while a prior policy remains active. Additionally, claims will not be paid if they fail to meet policy terms, if there is a misrepresentation, if requested information is not provided, if evidence is insufficient, or if necessary authorizations for information retrieval are not granted.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If you are legally competent to apply for a claim and your claim is accepted, all benefits will be paid to you or your legal personal representative. If your claim is accepted and you are judged to not be legally competent, we will pay any respective benefits to whomever we are legally permitted to make payments.
If the Policy is owned by a trustee of a complying superannuation fund and your claim is accepted, all benefits will be paid to the trustee.
We will not be liable to you for any loss you suffer (including consequential loss) caused by the fact that we are required by law to delay, block, freeze or refuse to process a transaction.
If a claimable event meets the requirements under the Terminal Illness Benefit, TPD Benefit and/or Critical Illness Benefit (where Plans are Attached or Linked), the Terminal Illness Benefit will be paid instead of the TPD Benefit or Critical Illness Benefit.
If cover is provided under Income Protection and a claim is made for a period of less than one month, it will be paid on a pro-rata basis. The payment will be made at a rate of 1/30th of the monthly amount payable for each day the Life Insured is entitled to any benefits payable under Income Protection.
ai_summary: Claims will be paid to the claimant or their legal representative if legally competent; otherwise, payments will be made to authorized individuals. For claims under a trustee-owned policy, benefits are paid to the trustee. The insurer is not liable for losses due to legal obligations affecting claim processing. In cases of Terminal Illness, Total Permanent Disability (TPD), or Critical Illness, the Terminal Illness Benefit takes precedence. For Income Protection claims under one month, payments are made pro-rata at a daily rate of 1/30th of the monthly benefit.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If the age of the Life Insured has been incorrectly provided and the premium paid is lower than required, any claim payments that are subsequently made will be reduced. If the premium paid is higher than required, any overpaid premiums will be refunded.
If the date of birth of the Life Insured has been incorrectly provided and the expiry date of the Policy would have been different had the correct date of birth been provided, then we may vary the Policy by changing its expiry date to the date that would have been the expiry date if the Policy had been based on the correct date of birth.
ai_summary: In the event of a misstatement of the Life Insured's age, claim payments will be adjusted based on the correct age; if premiums paid are lower than required, claims will be reduced, while overpaid premiums will be refunded if higher than necessary. Additionally, if the incorrect date of birth affects the policy's expiry date, the policy may be amended to reflect the correct expiry date based on the accurate date of birth.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: This page contains a large image of an adult wearing a white head covering, smiling and looking at a child who is also smiling and has their hands on the adult's face. The image takes up almost the entire page.
ai_summary: The content features an image illustrating a positive interaction between an adult and a child, but does not provide specific information regarding claims related to misstatement of age in insurance. Typically, such a section would address how inaccuracies in reporting an insured individual's age can affect policy benefits, coverage, or claims processing. It is essential for policyholders to accurately disclose their age to ensure proper underwriting and avoid potential claim denials.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Page 72 contains a large image of two men relaxing on a couch, one holding a mobile phone. There is no policy-related text content on this page, only the page number and document title in the footer.
ai_summary: Page 72 features an image of two men on a couch, with no accompanying policy-related text. Therefore, it does not provide any information regarding claims, misstatement of age, or any relevant insurance terms or concepts.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Accelerated Protection provides cover 24 hours a day, every day of the year, worldwide.
Some benefits may only be payable if the event giving rise to the claim occurs in Australia. Where this is the case, this is explained in this PDS. Some conditions also apply to claims where the Life Insured is not in Australia. See Section 3 for more information.
For Income Protection, if you are overseas, benefit payment will be limited to three months. See Section 2.6.4 for details.
ai_summary: Accelerated Protection offers worldwide coverage 24/7, with certain benefits contingent on events occurring in Australia, as detailed in the Product Disclosure Statement (PDS). Additionally, for Income Protection claims made while overseas, benefit payments are restricted to a maximum of three months, with further specifics outlined in Section 2.6.4.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: All premiums and benefits payable must be paid in Australian currency.
ai_summary: All premiums and benefits under this insurance policy must be paid in Australian currency, ensuring compliance with the specified monetary requirements for transactions related to the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: The Policy will be issued from TAL’s No. 1 Statutory Fund. The Policy will be non-participating which means that it does not entitle you to participate in the distribution of any surplus of the statutory fund.
ai_summary: The Policy is issued from TAL’s No. 1 Statutory Fund and is classified as non-participating, meaning policyholders will not have rights to any surplus distributions from the fund.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: If you or the Life Insured took reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation and answered all our questions accurately and you have paid all the premiums when due, Accelerated Protection will continue until the Plan end date. This guarantee of continuation applies regardless of any change in your health or personal circumstances.
ai_summary: Section 4.2 of the policy ensures that Accelerated Protection coverage will continue until the plan's end date, provided that the policyholder or Life Insured has answered all questions accurately, exercised reasonable care to avoid misrepresentation, and paid all premiums on time. This guarantee remains in effect regardless of any changes in health or personal circumstances.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: This PDS and all Accelerated Protection Policies issued by us will be interpreted in accordance with New South Wales law and is subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the Courts of Australia.
ai_summary: All Accelerated Protection Policies and this Product Disclosure Statement (PDS) will be governed by New South Wales law and are exclusively subject to the jurisdiction of Australian courts, ensuring clarity in legal interpretations and proceedings related to the policies.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Where future improvements are made to benefits or definitions under the Policy without increasing the premium rates, these improvements will be passed on to you. You will be notified of the changes and improvements via one or more of notice in writing, on our website or your adviser. In the unlikely event you are unexpectedly disadvantaged in any way, the former wording of the condition will apply. If the Life Insured has any existing symptoms before an improved condition being included, the Life Insured will be assessed on the former wording of the condition (if applicable).
ai_summary: Section 4.3 of the policy guarantees that any future enhancements to benefits or definitions will be provided to you without an increase in premium rates, with notifications sent via writing, website, or your adviser. If you are negatively impacted by these changes, the previous policy wording will apply, and any existing symptoms prior to the inclusion of improved conditions will be assessed under the former terms.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
The conditions of the Policy can be changed if required, but only if agreed to by both you and us. Changes to the Policy requested by you are subject to application. We reserve the right to require an Underwriting assessment to any Policy alteration that increases our obligation to pay a benefit. Any change must be confirmed in writing by an authorised member of our staff.
This section does not restrict our ability to change your Policy conditions as permitted under the Insurance Contracts Act if you or the Life Insured do not take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation.
ai_summary: Policy changes can be made only with mutual agreement between you and the insurer, and any requested alterations are subject to application and may require an underwriting assessment if they increase the insurer's obligations. All changes must be confirmed in writing by an authorized representative, and this section does not limit the insurer's right to amend policy conditions as allowed under the Insurance Contracts Act in cases of misrepresentation.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: All Plans and benefits outlined in this PDS don’t have a cash value if the Policy is cancelled. The premiums paid represent the amounts due for us undertaking the risk of the insured event occurring.
ai_summary: Section 4.4 of the policy states that all plans and benefits detailed in the Product Disclosure Statement (PDS) hold no cash value upon cancellation of the policy. The premiums paid are solely for the coverage provided against the risk of insured events, not as an investment or refundable amount.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: In some circumstances, we may agree to accept a voluntary increase in Benefit Amounts, even where a voluntary increase, if accepted, would result in the Benefit Amount exceeding the limits set out under the relevant Plan conditions. We may write to you from time to time to see if you wish to request a voluntary increase. Any request for voluntary increase is subject to the duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation to the insurer outlined in Section 5 and will involve a recalculation of your premium.
ai_summary: Section 4.9 of the policy outlines that policyholders may request a voluntary increase in Benefit Amounts, even if this exceeds the limits specified in the Plan conditions. Insurers may periodically reach out to offer this option; however, any request must adhere to the duty of reasonable care to avoid misrepresentation as detailed in Section 5, and will necessitate a recalculation of the premium.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
All premiums are payable by the due date shown in the Policy Schedule, unless we’ve offered an extension.
From the first Policy anniversary onwards, we’ll advise you of your new premium before each Policy anniversary.
If you make a claim, it is important to continue to pay premiums while we assess your claim until we tell you otherwise. This is important to ensure your cover is not cancelled.
ai_summary: Premiums must be paid by the due date specified in the Policy Schedule, unless an extension is granted. Policyholders will receive notification of the new premium prior to each Policy anniversary starting from the first anniversary. It is crucial to continue paying premiums while a claim is being assessed to avoid cancellation of coverage.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If you wish to cancel your Policy, you may be entitled to a refund of a proportion of the premium pursuant to our refund policy.
If your Policy is structured through superannuation, we may not be able to refund premiums to you but may be required to refund the premium as a contribution to an appropriate superannuation fund.
ai_summary: Section 4.10 outlines the cancellation and refund policy for your insurance. If you cancel your policy, you may receive a partial premium refund according to the refund policy; however, if your policy is linked to superannuation, refunds may be directed to the relevant superannuation fund instead of being returned to you directly.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: 4.13 Non-payment or late payment of premiums
content:
If we do not receive your premium payment by the due date, we’ll let you know in writing and give you at least 30 days to pay the overdue premium. If we do not receive the overdue premium by the date stated in the overdue notice, we will cancel your Policy.
If a claim is payable after your premium is due, but before your Policy/Plan is cancelled, we will pay the claim in line with the respective Policy/Plan conditions. When this occurs, any outstanding premiums will be deducted from the claim amount.
ai_summary: If premium payments are not received by the due date, the insurer will notify the policyholder in writing and allow a 30-day grace period to settle the overdue amount. Failure to pay within this timeframe will result in policy cancellation. However, if a claim arises after the premium is due but before cancellation, the insurer will honor the claim according to policy conditions, deducting any outstanding premiums from the claim payout.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
As long as your premium payments are received by the due date, your Policy will remain current until the Plan end date. This means your insurance Policy will continue regardless of any changes in your health, occupation, pastimes or income.
Your Policy may be cancelled if we do not receive a premium payment that is due. See Section 4.13 for more information.
Your Policy may be cancelled if you make a fraudulent claim or you do not comply with your duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation and we would not have provided you with the Policy had you complied with the duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation.
We will honour claim payments in line with the Policy terms and conditions if:
• The duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation has been complied with;
• You have answered all questions in your application honestly and accurately; and
• Your claim complies with relevant Australian laws.
ai_summary: Your insurance policy will remain active until the plan end date as long as premium payments are made on time, unaffected by changes in health or occupation. However, the policy may be cancelled for non-payment of premiums, fraudulent claims, or failure to comply with the duty of care regarding misrepresentation. Claims will be honored if the duty of care is met, all application questions are answered honestly, and the claim adheres to Australian laws.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: 4.14 What happens when your Policy is cancelled due to non-payment of premiums?
content:
If the Policy is cancelled due to non-payment of premiums, we may permit you to reinstate your Policy. We do not guarantee that reinstatement will be available to you. We reserve the right to decline to reinstate, offer amended terms or impose conditions on any cover offered.
You may be required to complete an application form and this may be subject to Underwriting (for example, we may require information about your health, lifestyle, pastimes, occupation and income).
If we offer to reinstate the Policy:
• Any special conditions and/or loadings which applied to your original Policy will also apply to the reinstated Policy.
• You must agree to any additional or amended terms offered to reinstate the Policy.
ai_summary: If your Policy is cancelled due to non-payment of premiums, reinstatement may be possible but is not guaranteed. You may need to complete an application form, which could involve underwriting based on your health and lifestyle. If reinstatement is offered, any special conditions or loadings from the original Policy will carry over, and you must accept any additional or amended terms for the reinstatement to be valid.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: 4.14 What happens when your Policy is cancelled due to non-payment of premiums?
content: • You must pay all outstanding premiums. We will inform you of the total outstanding premium amount as part of any offer of reinstatement we may make to you. • Your duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation (see Section 5) applies to any application for reinstatement. • Any reinstatement offered may be subject to additional terms and conditions other than those described in this clause. You will be informed of any additional terms and conditions at the time this option is offered to you. If reinstatement is not available to you, you can choose to apply for a new policy. This will be subject to an underwriting assessment and if cover is offered, the terms and premiums that apply for the new policy will be based on the current on-sale product available at the time of application.
ai_summary: If your policy is canceled due to non-payment of premiums, you must pay all outstanding amounts to be considered for reinstatement, which may come with additional terms. You are also required to avoid misrepresentation during the reinstatement application process. If reinstatement is not possible, you can apply for a new policy, which will undergo underwriting and be subject to current terms and premiums available at that time.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: If we reinstate the Policy, no benefit will be paid if the claim arises from: • any condition or Sickness including Terminal Illness which occurred, or where symptoms develop or were apparent to the Life Insured; or • any Injury or death that occurs, from the date the Policy was cancelled up to the date the Policy was reinstated.
ai_summary: The policy will not provide benefits for claims related to any condition or sickness, including terminal illness, that was present or had symptoms prior to the reinstatement of the policy. Additionally, no benefits will be paid for any injury or death occurring between the cancellation and reinstatement of the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Complaints about Accelerated Protection structured through superannuation
content: You should address your complaints to the trustee of your superannuation fund. The trustee will provide you with the details of its complaint-handling arrangements. If your Policy is structured though TAL Super, please refer the ‘How to make a complaint’ section of the Accelerated Protection through TAL Super PDS.
ai_summary: To address complaints regarding Accelerated Protection structured through superannuation, contact the trustee of your superannuation fund, who will outline their complaint-handling procedures. If your policy is with TAL Super, refer to the 'How to make a complaint' section in the Accelerated Protection through TAL Super Product Disclosure Statement (PDS) for specific guidance.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: If an issue has not been resolved to your satisfaction within 30 days of lodging your initial complaint, you can lodge a complaint with AFCA. You may wish to consult the AFCA website or contact AFCA directly to find out if there is a time limit on lodging a complaint with AFCA.

Be aware that time limits may apply for lodging complaints, so it's advisable to check the AFCA website or contact them directly for specific deadlines.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 5 Duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation
content:
When you apply for life insurance, we conduct a process called Underwriting. It’s how we decide whether we can cover you, and if so on what terms and for what premium.

We will ask questions we need to know the answers to. These will be about your personal circumstances, such as your health and medical history, occupation, income, lifestyle, pastimes, and current and past insurance. The information you give us in response to our questions is vital to our decision.

If your application is accepted, the Policy will be a consumer insurance contract.

You can find details of how we treat your personal information in our privacy policy in Section 6.
ai_summary: When applying for life insurance, you undergo Underwriting, where the insurer evaluates your eligibility and terms based on your personal information, including health, occupation, and lifestyle. Accurate disclosure of this information is crucial, as misrepresentation can affect your coverage; if accepted, your policy will be classified as a consumer insurance contract. For details on how your personal information is handled, refer to the privacy policy in Section 6.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 5 Duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation
Subheading: 5.1 The duty to take reasonable care
content:
When applying for insurance, there is a legal duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation to the insurer before the contract of insurance is entered into.

A misrepresentation is a false answer, an answer that is only partially true, or an answer which does not fairly reflect the truth.

This duty also applies when extending or making changes to existing insurance, and reinstating insurance.
ai_summary: Section 5.1 outlines the legal obligation for applicants to exercise reasonable care in avoiding misrepresentations when applying for insurance, which includes providing accurate and complete information. This duty extends to modifications or reinstatements of existing policies, ensuring that all disclosures are truthful and reflective of the actual circumstances to maintain the integrity of the insurance contract.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 5 Duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation
Subheading: 5.2 What can happen if the duty is not met?
content:
If you or the Life Insured do not take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation, there are different remedies that may be available to us. These are set out in the Insurance Contracts Act 1984 (Cth). These are intended to put us in the position we would have been in if the duty had been met.

For example, we may:
• avoid the cover (treat it as if it never existed);
• vary the amount of the cover; or
• vary the terms of the cover.

Whether we can exercise one of these remedies depends on a number of factors, including:
• whether you or the Life Insured took reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation. This depends on all of the relevant circumstances;
• what we would have done if the duty had been met – for example, whether we would have offered cover, and if so, on what terms;
• whether the misrepresentation was fraudulent; and
• in some cases, how long it has been since the cover started.

Before we exercise any of these remedies, we will explain our reasons, how to respond and provide further information, and what you can do if you disagree.
ai_summary: If you or the Life Insured fail to take reasonable care to avoid misrepresentation, remedies under the Insurance Contracts Act 1984 (Cth) may include voiding the coverage, altering the coverage amount, or changing the terms of the policy. The decision to apply these remedies depends on factors such as the nature of the misrepresentation, whether it was fraudulent, and the circumstances surrounding the duty of care. Prior to implementing any remedies, the insurer will provide explanations, guidance on responses, and information on disputing the decision.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 5 Duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation
content:
In addition to the information you have disclosed to us, we may require further information, including but not limited to medical, employment, and financial records about the Life Insured, to determine whether we are able to offer you cover and on what terms. We may require you to provide this further information to us. Alternatively, we may require your authority to obtain this information from one or more third parties, for example a treating medical practitioner, your employer or accountant.

If you do not provide the information that we require, or you do not authorise us to obtain the information we require from one or more third parties, we may not be able to assess your application or provide you with a Policy or Plan.
ai_summary: Section 5.3 outlines that, in addition to the initial disclosures, the insurer may request additional information, such as medical, employment, and financial records, to evaluate coverage eligibility and terms. Applicants must provide this information or authorize the insurer to obtain it from third parties; failure to do so may result in the inability to assess the application or issue a policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 5 Duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation
Subheading: 5.4 We can verify your compliance with your duty
content:
We have the right to verify whether what you have told us when you applied for your cover is accurate and complete. We may do this by comparing what you have told us to information contained in medical, financial, employment and other records about you.
We may require you to provide these records to us. Alternatively, we may require your authority to obtain these records from one or more third parties. If you do not provide the records we require, or you do not authorise us to obtain records about you that we require, we may refuse to assess or pay a claim you make against the Policy until the records are provided to us.
ai_summary: Insurers reserve the right to verify the accuracy and completeness of information provided during the application process by comparing it with medical, financial, and employment records. Policyholders may be required to supply these records or authorize the insurer to obtain them from third parties; failure to do so may result in the refusal to assess or pay claims until the necessary documentation is received.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: If you’re considering the tax implications of purchasing and receiving benefits under Accelerated Protection, it is important you seek independent, professional taxation advice. The complexity of taxation laws and rulings is such that this advice should be specific to your circumstances. This should include any tax implications of purchasing insurance cover structured through superannuation or outside of superannuation. The following general information only applies to Australian resident individuals and is based on the Australian tax law and rules as at the date of issue of this PDS. As noted above, benefit payments which are paid in substitute for income, or are in the nature of ordinary income, are generally considered assessable income and therefore should not also be subject to capital gains tax.
ai_summary: When considering the tax implications of purchasing Accelerated Protection, it is crucial to seek independent professional tax advice tailored to your specific situation, particularly regarding insurance structured through superannuation versus outside of it. This guidance is essential due to the complexity of Australian tax laws, as benefit payments that substitute for income are generally assessable and not subject to capital gains tax.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: We usually do not deduct or remit tax from benefit payments unless required to do so by law.
ai_summary: Benefit payments are typically not subject to tax withholding unless mandated by law, meaning that recipients may receive the full amount without deductions unless specific legal requirements dictate otherwise.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Accelerated Protection is treated as input taxed under the GST law and the premium will not be subjected to GST. The premium rates are inclusive of any GST costs incurred in relation to the Policy. An input tax credit will not be available to the Policy Owner.
ai_summary: Accelerated Protection is classified as input taxed under GST law, meaning that the premium is exempt from GST and is inclusive of any related GST costs. Consequently, the Policy Owner will not be eligible for an input tax credit on the premium paid.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: The following general information relates only to Australian resident individuals who are both the Policy Owner and the Life Insured. Superannuation law and tax law are complex, so it is important to seek professional advice specific to your circumstances.
ai_summary: Section 7.2 provides essential information for Australian resident individuals who are both the Policy Owner and the Life Insured regarding insurance held outside superannuation. It emphasizes the complexity of superannuation and tax laws, advising individuals to seek professional guidance tailored to their specific circumstances to ensure compliance and optimal financial outcomes.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: For Income Protection, premiums paid for insuring against loss of income and for benefits which are considered assessable income, should generally be tax deductible. Benefit payments which substitute for income, or are in the nature of ordinary income, are generally considered assessable income. This should not be the case for Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, Child’s Critical Illness Insurance and certain benefits under Income Protection. This may vary if insurance is taken out for business purposes and you should seek professional taxation advice.
ai_summary: Premiums paid for Income Protection insurance are typically tax-deductible, and benefit payments received as income are generally considered assessable income. However, this tax treatment does not apply to Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, Child’s Critical Illness Insurance, and certain Income Protection benefits. Tax implications may differ if the insurance is acquired for business purposes, so professional taxation advice is recommended.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Benefits payable under the Policy that are not assessable as ordinary income may be assessed under the capital gains tax provisions if you are not the original owner of the Policy and you acquired an interest in the Policy for consideration, or you received benefit payments from the Policy and fall outside of the exemption provisions.
ai_summary: Benefits from the Policy that are not classified as ordinary income may be subject to capital gains tax if you are not the original owner and acquired an interest in the Policy for consideration, or if you received benefit payments that do not qualify for exemption provisions.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: The following general information relates only to complying superannuation funds. Superannuation law and tax law are complex, so it is important to seek professional advice specific to your circumstances. From 1 July 2022, there have been changes to the eligibility age for downsizer contributions and in respect of the work test for personal superannuation contributions. From 1 July 2022, the minimum age to make downsizer contributions decreased to 60 years. This will allow some members aged 60 to 64 to potentially contribute $630,000 (or $1.26 million combined in the case of a couple) at one time by combining a downsizer contribution with the three-year non-concessional contributions bring-forward rule.
ai_summary: This section outlines changes effective from 1 July 2022 regarding superannuation contributions, specifically for complying funds. The minimum age for downsizer contributions has been lowered to 60, enabling individuals aged 60 to 64 to contribute up to $630,000 (or $1.26 million for couples) by utilizing both downsizer contributions and the three-year non-concessional contributions bring-forward rule. Due to the complexity of superannuation and tax laws, professional advice is recommended to navigate these changes effectively.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: You may be eligible for a tax deduction for your personal voluntary superannuation contributions. From 1 July 2022, if you are aged from 67 and 74 years, you will be able to make personal superannuation contributions without satisfying the work test, subject to existing contribution caps. However, you will still be required to meet the work test or work test exemption to claim a deduction for personal contributions. This test requires that you are gainfully employed for at least 40 hours in any consecutive 30 day period in the income year in which the contributions are made. The work test exemption applies to members aged from 67 and 74 who have a total super balance below $300,000 at the end of the prior 30 June and meet other conditions. It is your responsibility to ensure that you satisfy the work test or work test exemption for any personal contributions that you are claiming. To meet the work test exemption criteria, you must have: • satisfied the work test in the income year preceding the year in which you made the contribution; • a total super balance of less than $300,000 at the end of the previous income year; and • not relied on the work test exemption in a previous financial year.
ai_summary: From 1 July 2022, individuals aged 67 to 74 can make personal superannuation contributions without meeting the work test, provided they adhere to contribution caps. However, to claim a tax deduction for these contributions, they must either satisfy the work test—requiring at least 40 hours of gainful employment in a consecutive 30-day period—or qualify for a work test exemption, which is available if their total super balance is below $300,000 and they meet specific criteria. It is the member's responsibility to ensure compliance with these requirements.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Personal contributions which are claimed as a tax deduction are concessional contributions and are subject to the concessional contributions cap discussed below. Employer and salary sacrifice contributions are also concessional contributions.
The concessional contributions cap for the 2022/2023 financial year is $27,500 for members of all ages. From the 2019/2020 financial year, individuals with total superannuation balances of less than $500,000 on 30 June of the previous financial year, may be able to use their unused concessional contributions cap space to increase their concessional contributions cap.
Concessional contributions are generally included in the fund’s assessable income and may be subject to tax at the rate of 15% in the fund’s hands. However, where the member’s personal adjusted taxable income exceeds $250,000, the ATO will issue an assessment to the member assessing all or part of their concessional contributions to an additional 15% of tax.
Where concessional contributions in excess of the applicable cap are made in a financial year the ATO will issue the member an assessment taxing the excess at the member’s marginal tax rate (plus the Medicare levy). The member will be entitled to a tax offset equal to 15% of their excess concessional contributions (reflecting generally the tax already assessed to the recipient fund). An interest charge also applies for the deferral of tax.
ai_summary: Concessional contributions, including personal, employer, and salary sacrifice contributions, are capped at $27,500 for the 2022/2023 financial year and may be subject to a 15% tax within the fund. Individuals with superannuation balances under $500,000 can carry forward unused cap space from previous years. If a member's adjusted taxable income exceeds $250,000, an additional 15% tax may apply to their concessional contributions. Contributions exceeding the cap are taxed at the member's marginal rate, with a 15% tax offset available for the excess, alongside an interest charge for deferred tax payments.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
superannuation balances of $1.48 million or more have reduced (or no) access to the bring-forward rule.
If you receive an excess concessional or non-concessional contribution determination from the ATO, you should not elect for amounts to be released from TAL Super. TAL Super is unable to process a release authority from the ATO because you will not have an accumulation interest in TAL Super. In these circumstances if you require an amount to be released, you should nominate another superannuation fund in which you have a sufficient accumulation interest to make the release from.
If your income is less than $57,016 (for the 2022/2023 financial year), you may also benefit from government co-contributions if you make a personal after tax (non-concessional) contribution to your superannuation.
The government co-contribution is a payment made by the Federal Government to the superannuation account of eligible members who make personal non-concessional contributions. For more information contact your financial adviser or the Australian Tax Office (ATO) Superannuation Infoline on 13 10 20.
ai_summary: Superannuation balances of $1.48 million or more have limited access to the bring-forward rule, and if you receive an excess contribution determination from the ATO, you cannot release amounts from TAL Super due to insufficient accumulation interest. Instead, you should choose another super fund for the release. Additionally, individuals with an income below $57,016 for the 2022/2023 financial year may qualify for government co-contributions when making personal after-tax contributions to their superannuation. For further details, consult a financial adviser or the ATO Superannuation Infoline.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: If you are a low income earner and have eligible concessional superannuation contributions, you may be eligible for the low income superannuation tax offset, which is paid to your superannuation fund. There are also limits on the amount of post-tax or ‘non-concessional contributions’ that can be made on behalf of a member. Personal contributions for which you do not claim an income tax deduction and any excess concessional contributions that are not refunded by the fund, are non-concessional contributions. For the 2022/2023 financial year, the annual cap for non-concessional contributions is $110,000 and members with total superannuation balances of $1.7 million or more are not eligible to make non-concessional contributions. There is a ‘bring-forward’ option as discussed below. You will be taxed on non-concessional contributions over the cap at the rate of 45%, plus the Medicare levy where they cannot be released from a fund (and this is the case for TAL Super as stated below). Under the ‘bring-forward’ option, generally people under 75 years of age for at least one day during the year and have not accessed this option in prior years, can make non concessional contributions of up to three times the annual cap limit (explained above) in one year (other conditions apply). However, from 1 July 2022 members with total
ai_summary: Low-income earners with eligible concessional superannuation contributions may qualify for the low income superannuation tax offset, which is credited to their super fund. For the 2022/2023 financial year, the cap for non-concessional contributions is $110,000, with individuals holding total super balances of $1.7 million or more ineligible to contribute. Non-concessional contributions exceeding the cap are taxed at 45%, plus the Medicare levy. A 'bring-forward' option allows eligible individuals under 75 to contribute up to three times the annual cap in one year, provided they have not utilized this option in previous years.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Employers
Employer contributions are tax deductible to the employer where they are made to provide superannuation benefits for an employee or the employee’s dependants.
Employers can make contributions to complying superannuation funds for employees aged:
• under 75; or
• 75 and over, where contributions are required under legislation (such as the Superannuation Guarantee) or by relevant industrial awards.
ai_summary: Employer contributions to superannuation funds are tax deductible when made for employees or their dependants, applicable for employees under 75 years old or those 75 and over if mandated by legislation or industrial awards. This provision allows employers to fulfill their superannuation obligations while benefiting from tax deductions.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Tax payable on death benefits
Lump sum death benefits are tax free if paid to a dependant for tax purposes or the member’s estate where the beneficiaries of the estate are dependants of the member for tax purposes. Lump sum death benefits paid to non-dependants for tax purposes or the member’s estate to the extent the beneficiaries are not dependants for tax purposes, are taxed at different rates depending on whether the elements are from taxed or untaxed sources. For elements taxed in the fund, the rate is the lower of the recipient’s marginal tax rate and 15%, plus the Medicare levy. For elements untaxed in the fund, the rate is the lower of the recipient’s marginal tax rate and 30%, plus the Medicare levy. The trustee of the member’s estate does not bear the Medicare levy.
ai_summary: Lump sum death benefits are tax-free if paid to a tax-dependant or the member's estate with dependant beneficiaries. However, benefits paid to non-dependants are taxed based on the source of the funds: elements from taxed sources are taxed at the lower of the recipient's marginal tax rate or 15% (plus Medicare levy), while untaxed sources are taxed at the lower of the recipient's marginal tax rate or 30% (plus Medicare levy). The estate trustee is not responsible for the Medicare levy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Tax payable on Terminal Illness benefits
content:
Tax payable on Terminal Illness benefits
Terminal illness benefits paid to members are tax free.
ai_summary: Terminal illness benefits paid to members are exempt from taxation, meaning recipients will receive the full benefit amount without any tax deductions.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Total and Permanent Disablement (TPD) benefits are taxed at different rates, depending on the amount, the member’s age when they were disabled and their age at the date of payment.
ai_summary: Total and Permanent Disablement (TPD) benefits are subject to varying tax rates based on the benefit amount, the member's age at the time of disability, and their age at the payment date. Understanding these tax implications is crucial for beneficiaries to accurately assess their net benefits.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Tax payable on Income Protection benefits
content: Income Protection benefits, including the Super Contribution Option benefit, that substitute for lost income or are in the nature of ordinary income, should constitute assessable income of the claimant and should be taxed at the recipient’s marginal tax rate, plus the Medicare levy where applicable.
ai_summary: Income Protection benefits, including those from the Super Contribution Option, are considered assessable income for claimants and are subject to taxation at the recipient's marginal tax rate, along with the applicable Medicare levy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Where TAL or the trustee is required by law to deduct any tax, duty, impost or the like in connection with the payment of a benefit, TAL or the trustee will deduct the required amount from the payment and forward it to the relevant authority. For example, we will withhold tax from the Income Protection benefits that are in the nature of income (including the Super Contribution Option benefit), before the amounts are paid by us to the member or their nominated superannuation fund. This withholding tax arrangement applies for policies structured through TAL Super or certain retail superannuation funds. In other cases, the Policy Owner needs to consider the income and withholding tax implications upon receiving the Income Protection benefits and allocating the Super Contribution Option benefit to a nominated superannuation fund. We will also withhold tax from TPD and death benefits where required by law.
ai_summary: TAL or the trustee will deduct any legally required taxes, duties, or imposts from benefit payments, such as Income Protection benefits and TPD or death benefits, before disbursing them to the member or their nominated superannuation fund. This withholding tax applies to policies structured through TAL Super or certain retail superannuation funds, and Policy Owners should be aware of the income and withholding tax implications when receiving these benefits.
