Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 8 Important information on structuring insurance through superannuation
content:
You can choose to structure your Accelerated Protection through a complying superannuation fund. This means the trustee of the superannuation fund becomes the Policy Owner and you become a member of the fund.
When benefits are paid, they will be received by the trustee who will then distribute them in accordance with the governing rules of the superannuation fund and superannuation law.
Check with the trustee of your superannuation fund to see whether they can pay TAL your insurance premiums from your member account. This would be the case for most self-managed superannuation funds.
If you are not a member of a complying superannuation fund, or you are a member of a fund which cannot pay us insurance premiums from your member account, you can still take out Accelerated Protection through superannuation by becoming a member of TAL Super (see Accelerated Protection through TAL Super PDS). This applies to Life Insurance, TPD Insurance and Income Protection.
If you structure your Accelerated Protection through superannuation the taxation impacts may differ from holding insurance outside of superannuation, so it’s important to seek financial and taxation advice before you make this decision. Superannuation law is complex, so this advice should be specific to your circumstances. Please refer to the ‘Tax’ section for more information.
ai_summary: You can structure your Accelerated Protection insurance through a complying superannuation fund, where the fund's trustee becomes the Policy Owner and distributes benefits according to superannuation law. It's essential to verify if your superannuation fund can pay premiums to TAL from your member account, particularly for self-managed funds. If not, you can join TAL Super to obtain coverage. Be aware that structuring insurance through superannuation may have different tax implications compared to holding insurance outside of superannuation, so it's advisable to seek tailored financial and tax advice due to the complexity of superannuation law.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 8 Important information on structuring insurance through superannuation
content: Contributions can only be made to the superannuation fund in accordance with superannuation law. Superannuation law stipulates the way in which employer, personal, spousal and child contributions can be made, as well as work requirements and age limits in relation to the acceptance of superannuation contributions for members.
ai_summary: Contributions to a superannuation fund must comply with superannuation law, which outlines the regulations for employer, personal, spousal, and child contributions, including specific work requirements and age limits for acceptance. Understanding these legal stipulations is crucial for ensuring proper structuring of insurance within superannuation.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 8 Important information on structuring insurance through superannuation
content:
Superannuation law specifies that a death benefit can only be paid to the following:
• Member’s spouse (married or de facto, including same sex couples).
• Child of the member of any age (including adopted child, stepchild and ex-nuptial child).
• The member’s legal representative.
• Any person who was financially dependent on the member at the time of death.
• Any person with whom the member had an interdependency relationship.
If the trustee cannot locate any of these persons after conducting reasonable searches, the death benefit may be paid to an individual non-dependant such as a parent or sibling.
ai_summary: Under superannuation law, a death benefit can be paid to the member's spouse (including same-sex partners), children of any age (including adopted and stepchildren), the member's legal representative, or individuals who were financially dependent on the member or had an interdependency relationship with them. If these beneficiaries cannot be located after reasonable searches, the benefit may be paid to a non-dependent individual, such as a parent or sibling.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 8 Important information on structuring insurance through superannuation
content:
There are some important differences between owning your insurance yourself and purchasing your insurance through superannuation. For example, some benefits will not apply where insurance is held through superannuation (as set out in this PDS). However, in some circumstances purchasing insurance through superannuation may be more advantageous.
When Income Protection is structured through superannuation:
• A claim may not be payable if you were not ‘gainfully employed’ (as set out in SIS) immediately before your disability started.
• If you’re not ‘gainfully employed’ (as set out in SIS), you can apply to have your Plan suspended for up to 12 months.
If you are concerned or have any questions about the potential complications of structuring Income Protection through superannuation, you should speak to your financial adviser.
The following information is provided to assist you in understanding your options. It is general information only and is not intended to be a comprehensive statement of the laws applying to superannuation. You should talk to a financial adviser about your personal circumstances.
ai_summary: When structuring insurance through superannuation, key differences arise compared to personal ownership, including potential ineligibility for claims if not 'gainfully employed' prior to disability, as defined by SIS. While there are benefits to this approach, such as the ability to suspend your Plan for up to 12 months if not gainfully employed, it is essential to consult a financial adviser to navigate the complexities and ensure it aligns with your personal circumstances.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 8 Important information on structuring insurance through superannuation
content: Other than death benefits, a superannuation benefit can only be paid where the member meets a condition of release under applicable superannuation law. In a general sense, these circumstances include Permanent Incapacity, Temporary Incapacity, Terminal Medical Condition, retirement (or the person has reached their preservation age), the termination of employment after age 60, leaving Australia after holding an eligible temporary resident visa, and on financial hardship or compassionate grounds. Rules relating to when superannuation benefits can be accessed are complex, so you should consult a financial adviser for further information.
ai_summary: Superannuation benefits, excluding death benefits, can only be accessed when a member meets specific conditions of release as per superannuation law, such as Permanent or Temporary Incapacity, Terminal Medical Condition, retirement, termination of employment post-age 60, leaving Australia on an eligible visa, or experiencing financial hardship or compassionate grounds. Due to the complexity of these rules, consulting a financial adviser is recommended for detailed guidance.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 8 Important information on structuring insurance through superannuation
content:
Provisions in the Family Law Act enable parties who are married to require superannuation fund trustees to carry out certain actions in relation to superannuation entitlements. Members should note that their spouse or de-facto will be able to request the trustee to disclose information about the member’s benefit entitlements ('Request for Information').
The trustee is prohibited by law from informing members that such a request was made. The trustee will not pass any information about your present whereabouts to the person making the Request for Information.
ai_summary: Under the Family Law Act, spouses or de-facto partners can request superannuation fund trustees to disclose information regarding a member's entitlements, known as a 'Request for Information.' However, trustees are legally obligated to keep the member unaware of such requests and will not disclose any information about the member's current location to the requesting party.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 8 Important information on structuring insurance through superannuation
content: If you’re structuring Accelerated Protection through TAL Super, you should also read the ‘Accelerated Protection through TAL Super PDS’ together with this PDS. It contains specific information about to structuring Accelerated Protection through TAL Super.
ai_summary: When structuring Accelerated Protection through TAL Super, it is essential to review the 'Accelerated Protection through TAL Super PDS' in conjunction with this PDS, as it provides critical details regarding the specific terms, benefits, and requirements associated with this insurance arrangement.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 8 Important information on structuring insurance through superannuation
content: Some superannuation funds are prevented from making rollovers to pay for insurance cover through superannuation – you should check whether your superannuation fund is able to pay a rollover.
ai_summary: Certain superannuation funds may not allow rollovers to finance insurance coverage, so it is essential to verify whether your specific superannuation fund permits such transactions before proceeding with insurance structuring through superannuation.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Section_Title: 8 Important information on structuring insurance through superannuation
Subheading: 8.6 Risk of holding insurance through superannuation
content:
There are risks you should consider before deciding to hold insurance through superannuation, including:
• Except for Income Protection benefits, a benefit paid from a policy structured through superannuation is a superannuation benefit for tax purposes and it may be subject to more tax than would otherwise apply if the benefit was paid from the same insurance held outside of superannuation.
• Limits apply to the amount you can contribute to superannuation each year. Any contributions you make to a superannuation fund in order to pay premiums will reduce the amount you may be able to contribute to other superannuation accounts you hold for retirement savings purposes.
• Where you choose to pay premiums by rollover from another superannuation fund, your retirement savings will be reduced so that you may have less available to you on retirement than otherwise may have been the case. You should ensure that the cost of premiums do not inappropriately erode your retirement savings.
• Taxation or superannuation laws may change in the future, altering the suitability of holding insurance through superannuation.
ai_summary: When considering insurance through superannuation, be aware of several risks: benefits, except for Income Protection, may incur higher taxes as superannuation benefits; contributions for premiums can limit your overall superannuation contributions for retirement savings; using rollover funds for premiums may reduce your retirement savings; and potential future changes in taxation or superannuation laws could affect the viability of this insurance structure.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Accident or Accidental means an accident caused wholly by violent, accidental, external and visible means.
ai_summary: In insurance terms, "Accident" or "Accidental" refers to an event resulting from violent, external, and visible forces, indicating that the cause of the incident must be entirely due to these specific factors. This definition is crucial for determining coverage eligibility and claims related to accidental injuries or damages.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Activities of daily living (ADL) are:
• Bathing – The ability for the Life Insured to wash themselves either in the bath or shower. If the Life Insured performs these tasks by using equipment or adaptive devices, we will consider them able to bathe themselves.
• Dressing – The ability for the Life Insured to put on and take off all garments. If the Life Insured is using modified clothing or adaptive devices including but not limited to tape fasteners or zipper pulls to perform this task, we will consider the Life Insured able to dress themselves.
• Feeding – The ability for the Life Insured to get food from a plate into the mouth once it has been prepared. If the Life Insured is able to perform this task using assistive devices including but not limited to modified utensils and adaptive dinnerware, we will consider the Life Insured able to feed themselves.
• Toileting – The ability for the Life Insured to get on and off the toilet and clean themselves. If the Life Insured can care for a stoma or catheter or uses adaptive devices to perform this task, we will consider them able to toilet themselves.
• Mobility – The ability for the Life Insured to move in and out of bed and a chair. If the Life Insured uses motorised equipment and supportive devices including but not limited to bed rails, grab bars, walkers, transfer platforms and canes, we will consider the Life Insured able to mobilise themselves.
ai_summary: Activities of daily living (ADL) include bathing, dressing, feeding, toileting, and mobility, which are essential for assessing the Life Insured's ability to perform self-care tasks. The use of adaptive devices or modified clothing does not negate the ability to perform these activities; thus, individuals utilizing such aids may still be considered capable of completing each ADL.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Any Occupation under Income Protection means an occupation that the Life Insured is suited for after considering the Life Insured’s work experience, training, education and transferable skills regardless of whether the work or employment is available.
An occupation that a Life Insured is reasonably suited for includes suitable alternate occupations where up-skilling is required, and the training course/program can be completed within 12 months on a full-time basis or 24 months on a part-time basis.
ai_summary: In the context of Income Protection, "Any Occupation" refers to a job that the Life Insured is deemed suited for based on their work experience, training, education, and transferable skills, regardless of job availability. This includes suitable alternate occupations that may require up-skilling, provided that the necessary training can be completed within 12 months full-time or 24 months part-time.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Attached or Attaching means where under one Policy:
• Critical Illness insurance is added as a benefit to Life insurance;
• TPD insurance is added as a benefit to Life insurance; or
• TPD insurance is added as a benefit to Critical Illness insurance.
A payment under one will affect a corresponding reduction in the Benefit Amount payable under the other (Attached) insurance and a reduction in the total premium payable.
ai_summary: "Attached or Attaching" refers to the integration of Critical Illness and Total Permanent Disability (TPD) insurance as benefits within a Life insurance policy. When these benefits are combined, a payment from one will result in a corresponding decrease in the Benefit Amount of the other insurance and will also reduce the total premium payable.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Bed Confined and Bed Confinement mean the Life Insured has been advised by a Medical Practitioner to remain in or near a bed for a substantial part of each day and under the continuous care of a Registered Nurse.
ai_summary: "Bed Confined" and "Bed Confinement" refer to a situation where the Life Insured is instructed by a Medical Practitioner to stay in or near a bed for a significant portion of each day, necessitating continuous care from a Registered Nurse. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for certain benefits under the insurance policy related to medical care and support.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Benefit Amount under Income Protection means the monthly amount as calculated below.
Benefit Amount at the start of the Waiting Period is the lesser of the following:
• the Benefit Amount shown in your Policy Schedule, plus any increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit (if applicable); or
• 70% of the first $20,000 per month ($240,000 per annum) of your Pre-Claim Earnings; 50% of the next $20,000 per month ($240,000 per annum) of your Pre-Claim Earnings; and 20% of the remainder of your Pre-Claim Earnings.
If you have more than one income protection cover with us, the Benefit Amount will be adjusted so that the accumulated total income replacement benefit that you receive cannot exceed 70% of the first $20,000 per month ($240,000 per annum) of the Pre-Claim Earnings; 50% of the next $20,000 per month ($240,000 per annum) of the Pre-Claim Earnings; and 20% of the remainder of the Pre-Claim Earnings.
Benefit Amount will incorporate increases under the Increasing Claim Option (if applicable).
ai_summary: The Benefit Amount under Income Protection is the monthly payment determined at the start of the Waiting Period, calculated as the lesser of the amount specified in the Policy Schedule (including any applicable Inflation Protection) or a percentage of the insured's Pre-Claim Earnings, specifically 70% of the first $20,000, 50% of the next $20,000, and 20% of any remaining earnings. If multiple income protection policies are held, the total benefit will be adjusted to ensure it does not exceed these limits, and any increases under the Increasing Claim Option will be factored into the Benefit Amount.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Benefit Amount under Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance and Child's Critical Illness Insurance
content:
Benefit Amount under Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance and Child's Critical Illness Insurance is the respective lump sum amount shown in the Policy Schedule as applicable, after taking into account increases or reductions, applied:
• Under the conditions of Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness insurance and Child's Critical Illness Insurance or options; or
• In line with a request by you that is agreed to by us.
ai_summary: The Benefit Amount for Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, and Child's Critical Illness Insurance is the specified lump sum in the Policy Schedule, subject to adjustments based on policy conditions or approved requests from the policyholder.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Benefit Period under Income Protection means the maximum Claim Period for any one Sickness or Injury or related Sickness or Injury. The maximum Benefit Period is shown in your Policy Schedule.
ai_summary: The Benefit Period in Income Protection insurance refers to the maximum duration for which claims can be made due to a single Sickness or Injury, or related conditions. The specific length of the Benefit Period is detailed in the Policy Schedule.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Carer means the Life Insured provides everyday care to an Immediate Family Member due to disability or injury to enable them to live at home. The care must be necessary for medical reasons and have not been required before the Policy commencement. It must also be, in the opinion of a Medical Practitioner, likely to be required for a continuous period of at least six months.
ai_summary: A "Carer" is defined as the Life Insured who provides essential everyday care to an Immediate Family Member due to a disability or injury, allowing them to remain at home. This care must be medically necessary, not previously required before the policy's commencement, and expected to continue for at least six months, as determined by a Medical Practitioner.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Child Insured means the child insured under the Child's Critical Illness Insurance Plan.
ai_summary: The term "Child Insured" refers to a child covered under the Child's Critical Illness Insurance Plan, which provides financial protection in the event of specified critical illnesses affecting the insured child. This designation is essential for understanding the scope of coverage and benefits available under the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Claim Period means the total length of time that the Life Insured qualifies for the Totally Unable To Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit after the Waiting Period.
ai_summary: The Claim Period refers to the duration during which the Life Insured is eligible to receive either the Totally Unable To Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit, following the completion of the Waiting Period.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Earnings means:
• if the Life Insured is Self-Employed, their share of the total of all net profits and all net losses generated or accrued in the normal conduct of the business or businesses, after excluding business expenses which were not necessarily incurred or normally required in the usual and normal conduct of the business/businesses; or
• if the Life Insured is an Employee (and is not Self-Employed), salary, wages, regular bonuses and any other income considered part of the Life Insured’s remuneration package (excluding any Employer Superannuation Contribution).
Income paid from other disability income policies, retirement plans, lump sum disability payments, rental income and investment income are some examples of income we would not consider as Earnings.
ai_summary: Earnings, as defined in this insurance document, refers to the income of the Life Insured based on their employment status: for Self-Employed individuals, it encompasses their net profits and losses from business activities after excluding non-essential expenses; for Employees, it includes salary, wages, regular bonuses, and other remuneration components, excluding Employer Superannuation Contributions. Notably, income from other disability policies, retirement plans, lump sum disability payments, rental income, and investment income are explicitly excluded from the definition of Earnings.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Employer Superannuation Contribution means the employer superannuation guarantee contribution mandated under the Superannuation Guarantee Administration Act and any employer contribution made as part of the Life Insured’s remuneration package. It excludes any other type of superannuation contribution.
ai_summary: The Employer Superannuation Contribution refers to the mandatory contributions required by the Superannuation Guarantee Administration Act, as well as any additional contributions included in the Life Insured’s remuneration package. It specifically excludes all other forms of superannuation contributions.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Employee means the Life Insured is hired for a wage, salary, fee or payment to perform work for an employer, whereby they have no direct or indirect ownership interest in the employing entity (ignoring shares in publicly listed companies).
ai_summary: In the context of insurance, an "Employee" refers to an individual who is compensated through wages, salaries, fees, or other payments for work performed for an employer, without holding any direct or indirect ownership interest in the employer, except for shares in publicly traded companies. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility and coverage under life insurance policies.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Exposure Prone Procedures means contact by the skin with sharp surgical instruments, needles, or splinters of bone or teeth in poorly visualised or confined body sites.
ai_summary: Exposure Prone Procedures refer to medical practices where there is direct skin contact with sharp instruments, needles, or bone/tooth fragments in areas of the body that are difficult to visualize or access. Understanding this definition is crucial for insurance coverage related to potential risks and liabilities associated with such procedures.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Immediate Family Member means spouse, partner, de-facto, children, parents and siblings.
ai_summary: The term "Immediate Family Member" in this insurance document encompasses a spouse, partner, de-facto partner, children, parents, and siblings, which may be relevant for determining coverage, benefits, or eligibility for claims related to family-related events or circumstances.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Indexation Factor is the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index (Weighted Average All Capital Cities) as last published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in respect of the 12-month period finishing on 30 September of each year.
This factor will be determined at 30 November each year and applied, where indicated, for the following calendar year. If it is not published by 30 November, the Indexation Factor will be calculated based upon a retail price index we consider replaces it.
If the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index, or any substitute for it, is negative, the Indexation Factor will be taken as zero.
ai_summary: The Indexation Factor is defined as the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) as published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the 12-month period ending on September 30 each year. This factor is determined by November 30 and applied for the subsequent calendar year; if the CPI is not available, a suitable retail price index will be used instead. In cases where the CPI change is negative, the Indexation Factor will be set to zero, ensuring that it does not decrease.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Injury means a bodily injury suffered by the Life Insured or Child Insured.
ai_summary: In the context of this insurance document, "Injury" refers specifically to a bodily injury sustained by either the Life Insured or the Child Insured, establishing the scope of coverage for physical harm under the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Life Insured means the person whose life is insured under the Life Insurance Plan, TPD Insurance Plan, Critical Illness Insurance Plan or Income Protection Plan.
ai_summary: The term "Life Insured" refers to the individual whose life is covered under various insurance plans, including the Life Insurance Plan, Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Insurance Plan, Critical Illness Insurance Plan, or Income Protection Plan.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Limb means an arm, leg, hand or foot. In respect of this definition, the hand or foot starts from the wrist or ankle joint, respectively.
ai_summary: In the context of this insurance document, "Limb" is defined as an arm, leg, hand, or foot, with the hand and foot specifically referring to the portions extending from the wrist and ankle joints, respectively. This definition is crucial for determining coverage and benefits related to injuries or conditions affecting these body parts.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Linked or Linking means the connection of two separate Policies whereby the payment under a Plan purchased under one Policy effects a corresponding reduction in the Benefit Amount payable under the other (Linked) Policy and a reduction in the total premium payable.
ai_summary: "Linked or Linking" refers to the relationship between two separate insurance Policies, where a payment made under one Policy results in a corresponding decrease in the Benefit Amount of the other Policy, as well as a reduction in the total premium owed. This mechanism allows for coordinated coverage and potential cost savings for policyholders.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Long Term Leave is any leave period longer than four weeks such as any unpaid leave, maternity or paternity leave, a sabbatical, or leave taken to allow you to work for a charitable organisation.
ai_summary: Long Term Leave refers to any leave exceeding four weeks, which includes unpaid leave, maternity or paternity leave, sabbaticals, or leave for charitable work. This definition is crucial for understanding eligibility and coverage under insurance policies related to extended absences from work.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Loss of Independent Existence (permanent) means that solely because of Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured:
• is totally and permanently unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without the physical assistance of another person; or
• suffers permanent Significant Cognitive Impairment.
ai_summary: Loss of Independent Existence (permanent) refers to a condition where the Life Insured, due to Sickness or Injury, is unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without assistance from another person, or experiences permanent Significant Cognitive Impairment. This definition outlines the criteria for qualifying for certain insurance benefits related to total and permanent disability.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent)
content: Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable loss of use of one Limb.
ai_summary: Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent) refers to the complete and irreversible inability to use one limb, which is a critical definition in determining eligibility for certain insurance benefits related to permanent disabilities. This condition must be clearly documented to qualify for claims under relevant policies.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Loss of use of Limbs (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable loss of use of two or more Limbs.
ai_summary: "Loss of use of Limbs (permanent)" refers to the complete and irreversible inability to use two or more limbs, which may be relevant for determining eligibility for certain insurance benefits or claims related to permanent disability.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent)
content: Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent) means the permanent and irrecoverable loss of sight (whether aided or unaided) in one eye, because of Sickness or Injury to the extent that visual acuity in the eye, on a Snellen Scale after correction by a suitable lens is less than 6/60, or to the extent that the visual field is reduced to 20 degrees or less of arc.
ai_summary: "Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent)" refers to the irreversible loss of vision in one eye due to Sickness or Injury, defined as having a visual acuity of less than 6/60 on the Snellen Scale, even with corrective lenses, or a visual field reduced to 20 degrees or less. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for benefits under the insurance policy related to permanent vision impairment.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Maximum Medical Improvement means that the Life Insured’s recovery from the Sickness or Injury has reached a point where no further recovery or functional improvement is expected even with additional intervention or treatment (medical and non-medical). We will consider all medical information from the Life Insured’s medical providers and will seek independent medical specialist opinion if required, to determine whether Maximum Medical Improvement has been achieved.
ai_summary: Maximum Medical Improvement (MMI) refers to the stage in which the Life Insured's recovery from a Sickness or Injury has stabilized, indicating that no further recovery or enhancement in function is anticipated, even with additional treatment. The determination of MMI will involve reviewing medical information from the Life Insured’s healthcare providers and may include consultations with independent medical specialists if necessary.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Medical Practitioner means a person who is legally qualified and registered as a Medical Practitioner, other than:
• you or the Life Insured;
• a business partner of yours or the Life Insured; or
• an Immediate Family Member of you or the Life Insured.
If practising other than in Australia, the Medical Practitioner must be approved by us, acting reasonably, and have qualifications equivalent to Australian standards.
Note: Chiropractors, physiotherapists, psychologists and alternative therapy providers are not regarded as Medical Practitioners.
ai_summary: A Medical Practitioner, for insurance purposes, is a legally qualified and registered individual who is not you, the Life Insured, a business partner, or an Immediate Family Member. If practicing outside Australia, their qualifications must be equivalent to Australian standards and approved by the insurer. Notably, chiropractors, physiotherapists, psychologists, and alternative therapy providers do not qualify as Medical Practitioners under this definition.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: MSAL refers to Mercer Superannuation (Australia) Limited (ABN 79 004 717 533) (AFSL 235906) as the trustee of TAL Super.
ai_summary: MSAL stands for Mercer Superannuation (Australia) Limited, identified by ABN 79 004 717 533 and AFSL 235906, which serves as the trustee for TAL Super. This designation is crucial for understanding the governance and management of superannuation funds within the insurance framework.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Own Occupation under Income Protection means the
ai_summary: The term "Own Occupation" in the context of Income Protection insurance refers to the policyholder's ability to claim benefits if they are unable to perform the duties of their specific job due to illness or injury, regardless of their capacity to work in other roles. This definition emphasizes the importance of the individual's occupation in determining eligibility for benefits, ensuring that coverage is tailored to their unique professional circumstances.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
occupation or business in which the Life Insured was working immediately before the start of the Waiting Period, unless the Life Insured:
• was Unemployed or on Long Term Leave for more than 12 consecutive months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period, ‘Own Occupation’ will be replaced with ‘Any Occupation’; or
• was Unemployed or on Long Term Leave for less than 12 consecutive months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period, ‘Own Occupation’ means the most recent occupation in which the Life Insured was working prior to the start of the Waiting Period.
If you are Self-Employed or work on a contract basis and you have not performed any duties that directly generate income, or your business has not generated any income for more than 12 consecutive months before the start of the Waiting Period, ‘Own Occupation’ has the same meaning as ‘Any Occupation’.
If the Life Insured had been working in more than one occupation that meets these criteria, ‘Own Occupation’ will include all of those occupations.
ai_summary: The term "Own Occupation" refers to the job the Life Insured was engaged in immediately before the Waiting Period, unless they were unemployed or on long-term leave for over 12 months, in which case it defaults to "Any Occupation." If the Life Insured was unemployed or on leave for less than 12 months, "Own Occupation" pertains to their most recent job. For self-employed individuals or contractors who have not generated income for over 12 months, "Own Occupation" is also defined as "Any Occupation." If the Life Insured held multiple qualifying occupations, all will be considered under "Own Occupation."

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Own Occupation under Life Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance and TPD Insurance is the occupation in which the Life Insured was working immediately before the Sickness or Injury causing disability.
If the Life Insured had been working in more than one occupation that meets these criteria, ‘Own Occupation’ will include all of those occupations.
ai_summary: The term "Own Occupation" in Life Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, and Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Insurance refers to the specific job the insured was engaged in immediately prior to a sickness or injury that leads to disability. If the insured held multiple relevant occupations at that time, all such occupations will be considered under "Own Occupation" for the purposes of the policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Partially Unable to Work means that solely because of Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is:
• working (whether or not for remuneration) in a reduced capacity or capable of working in a reduced capacity;
• following the advice and treatment plan of a Medical Practitioner in relation to the Sickness or Injury; and
• not capable of working more than 80% of the Life Insured’s usual average working hours in the 12 months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period. The usual average working hours immediately before the start of the Waiting Period will be limited to 40 hours a week (if the Life Insured is working more than 40 hours a week).
Where Income Protection has been structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition for Temporary Incapacity or Permanent Incapacity.
ai_summary: "Partially Unable to Work" refers to a situation where, due to Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is either working or capable of working in a reduced capacity, adheres to a Medical Practitioner’s treatment plan, and cannot work more than 80% of their average hours from the previous 12 months, capped at 40 hours per week if applicable. Additionally, for Income Protection through superannuation, the Life Insured must meet the SIS criteria for Temporary or Permanent Incapacity.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Plan means the insurance benefits and applicable options under Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, Child’s Critical Illness Insurance and Income Protection, depending on the terms of the applicable Policy Schedule, that apply to you when your Policy is in force.
ai_summary: The term "Plan" refers to the specific insurance benefits and options available to you under various policies, including Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, Child’s Critical Illness Insurance, and Income Protection, as outlined in your Policy Schedule while the policy is active.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Policy means the Accelerated Protection Policy under the terms and conditions set out in this PDS.
ai_summary: The term "Policy" refers to the Accelerated Protection Policy as outlined in the Product Disclosure Statement (PDS), which details the specific terms and conditions governing the coverage provided.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Policy Owner means the person or company that legally owns the Policy. Where Accelerated Protection is structured through a superannuation fund, the trustee of that superannuation fund will be the Policy Owner that holds the Policy on behalf of the member.
ai_summary: The Policy Owner is the individual or entity that legally holds the insurance policy. In cases where the Accelerated Protection is arranged through a superannuation fund, the trustee of that fund acts as the Policy Owner, managing the policy on behalf of the fund member.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Policy Schedule refers to the documentation that identifies the Policy Owner, the Life Insured, the type of Plan(s) and options applicable to the Policy, the amount of coverage, the special conditions that apply, the Plan start and end date and premium details (amount and payment frequency). The Policy Schedule is a legal document and forms part of the insurance contract.
ai_summary: The Policy Schedule is a crucial legal document within the insurance contract that outlines key details such as the Policy Owner, Life Insured, applicable Plan types and options, coverage amounts, special conditions, Plan duration, and premium details, including amount and payment frequency.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Pre-Claim Earnings under Income Protection means:
• if Self-Employed, the Life Insured’s average Earnings over the last two financial years that have ended immediately before the start of the Waiting Period; or
• if an Employee (and the Life Insured is not Self-Employed), the Life Insured’s average Earnings over the consecutive 12-month period immediately before the start of the Waiting Period.
Pre-Claim Earnings will increase by the Indexation Factor on each anniversary from the start of the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit becomes payable.
If the Life Insured has been on Long Term Leave or was Unemployed for up to 12 months prior to the start of the Waiting Period, Pre-Claim Earnings will be calculated based on the period immediately before the Life Insured went on Long Term Leave or became Unemployed.
If Income Protection is structured through superannuation, the SIS rules and regulation must be met.
ai_summary: Pre-Claim Earnings for Income Protection are defined as the average earnings of the Life Insured over the last two financial years for self-employed individuals, or the average earnings over the preceding 12 months for employees. These earnings will be adjusted annually by the Indexation Factor once the Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work Benefit is activated. If the Life Insured has been on Long Term Leave or unemployed for up to 12 months before the Waiting Period, earnings will be calculated based on the period prior to their leave or unemployment. Additionally, if the Income Protection is through superannuation, compliance with SIS rules and regulations is required.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Rehabilitation Program means a program or plan:
• designed to assist the Life Insured in returning to a Working Occupation; and
• developed by an appropriately qualified vocational or occupational rehabilitation specialist.
General medical consultations and medical therapy consultations, including but not limited to, physiotherapy, psychotherapy and hydrotherapy, are excluded.
ai_summary: The Rehabilitation Program is a structured initiative aimed at helping the Life Insured regain their Working Occupation, crafted by a qualified vocational or occupational rehabilitation specialist. It is important to note that general medical consultations and therapies, such as physiotherapy, psychotherapy, and hydrotherapy, are not covered under this program.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Self-Employed means the Life Insured directly or indirectly owns all or part of the business in which their work is performed including where the business operates under a company structure (ignoring shares in publicly listed companies).
ai_summary: The term "Self-Employed" refers to the Life Insured who owns, either wholly or partially, the business in which they work, including those operating under a company structure, while excluding shares in publicly traded companies. This definition is crucial for determining coverage and eligibility under the insurance policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Serious and Permanent Incapacity or Seriously and Permanently Incapacitated
ai_summary: "Serious and Permanent Incapacity" refers to a condition where the Life Insured, due to Sickness or Injury, experiences permanent incapacity meeting specific severity criteria. Additionally, mental illnesses are evaluated exclusively under their designated category, and for chronic pain conditions, the insured must have engaged in an accredited multi-disciplinary pain management program and received care from a pain specialist for a minimum of six months, with no anticipated functional improvement.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Category: Cardiac and respiratory condition
Serious Incapacity requirement: The Life Insured meets one of the following:
• suffers an irreversible respiratory condition and is on permanent oxygen therapy; or
• suffers an irreversible cardiac condition to the degree of at least Class 3 of the New York Heart Association Classification.

Category: Mental illness
Serious Incapacity requirement: The Life Insured has a diagnosed mental disorder, and solely due to the mental disorder meets at least four of the following:
• Self-care and independent living: Cannot live independently without regular support. Needs prompting to shower daily and wear clean clothes. Is not able to prepare own meals and frequently misses meals if not prompted to eat. Requires family member or community nurse visits 3 times every week to ensure minimum level of hygiene and nutrition.
• Social and/or recreational activities: Rarely goes out to social and/or recreational events, and only when prompted by family member or close friend. Not actively involved, remains quiet and withdrawn.
• Travel: Cannot travel away from own residence without support person due to severe anxiety or cognitive impairment.
• Social functioning: Unable to form or sustain long term relationships and loss of most pre-existing relationships (e.g. lost partner, close friends). Unable to care for dependants (e.g. own children, elderly parent).
• Concentration: Can only read a few lines of text before losing concentration. Has difficulty following simple instructions. Concentration deficits obvious even during brief conversation. Needs regular assistance from relatives or community services.

Category: Cognitive impairment (impairment as a result of Sickness or Injury other than mental illness)
Serious Incapacity requirement: The Life Insured suffers a deterioration or loss of intellectual capacity that results in a requirement for a full-time permanent caregiver.

Category: Blindness
Serious Incapacity requirement: The Life Insured has permanent and irrecoverable loss of sight in of both eyes as a result of Sickness or Injury to the extent that visual acuity in both eyes, on a Snellen Scale after correction by suitable lens is less than 6/60, or to the extent that the visual field is reduced to 20 degrees or less of arc. Visual acuity cannot be improved with corrective lenses or surgery.

Category: Terminal conditions
Serious Incapacity requirement: The Life Insured has an incurable Sickness or Injury and:
• has a life expectancy of less than 12 months; or
• requires palliative care (i.e. care or treatment to improve the quality of living). The palliative care must be provided by an accredited medical provider/facility.

Category: Universal
Serious Incapacity requirement: The Life Insured is totally and permanently unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without the physical assistance of another person.
The Life Insured is considered capable of performing the task if they can perform the task using or wearing any prosthesis or assistive device that is appropriate.

Category: Specified conditions
Serious Incapacity requirement: The Life Insured has been unequivocally diagnosed by an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner with one of the following:
• paraplegia, diplegia, hemiplegia or quadriplegia
• end stage chronic kidney, lung, heart or liver failure
• motor neurone disease
• dementia
• Parkinson’s disease
ai_summary: This section outlines the "Serious Incapacity" requirements for various categories affecting the Life Insured. For cardiac and respiratory conditions, eligibility includes irreversible conditions requiring permanent oxygen therapy or significant cardiac impairment. Mental illness requires a diagnosed disorder with severe functional limitations in self-care, social activities, travel, and concentration. Cognitive impairment necessitates full-time caregiving due to intellectual decline. Blindness is defined by permanent loss of sight in both eyes that cannot be corrected. Terminal conditions are characterized by a life expectancy of under 12 months or the need for palliative care. Universal incapacity involves being unable to perform at least two Activities of Daily Living without assistance. Lastly, specified conditions include severe diagnoses such as paraplegia, end-stage organ failure, and

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Sickness means an illness or disease suffered by the Life Insured or Child Insured, as confirmed by a Medical Practitioner.
Significant Cognitive Impairment means a deterioration or loss of intellectual capacity that results in a requirement for a full-time permanent caregiver.
SIS means the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (Cth) or the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulation 1994 (Cth), as applicable.
SMSF means self-managed superannuation fund.
Standalone means Plans which are held independently of each other and when a benefit is paid under one Plan it does not reduce the Benefit Amount for any other Standalone Plans held.
Structured through superannuation means Accelerated Protection is owned by the trustee of a fund (which may be TAL Super, a retail superannuation fund which we have an agreement with or a self-managed superannuation fund) for one or more members of the fund.
Super Contribution Benefit Amount under the Super Contribution Option means the monthly benefit shown in your Policy Schedule plus any increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit.
Superlink or Superlinked means the connection of two separate Policies, one issued to the trustee of a superannuation fund and the other issued outside of superannuation. In the event no amount is payable under the Policy structured through superannuation, or the amount payable is restricted, a payment may be made through the Policy structured outside superannuation, subject to the Life Insured meeting the terms and conditions. The maximum benefits payable under both Policies will never exceed the amount that would have been payable under a single Policy structured outside superannuation.
TAL Services means TAL Services Limited (ACN 076 105 130), a related body corporate of TAL that provides administration and other services in relation to TAL Super.
TAL Super means a plan within the Retail Division in the Mercer Super Trust (ABN 19 905 422 981) sponsored by TAL Services Limited.
Terminally Ill and Terminal Illness means an illness or condition where, after having regard to the current treatment or such treatment as the Life Insured may reasonably be expected to receive, the Life Insured has a life expectancy of less than 12 months.
When Life Insurance is structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Terminal Medical Condition.
ai_summary: This section defines key insurance terms: "Sickness" refers to an illness confirmed by a medical practitioner, while "Significant Cognitive Impairment" indicates a loss of intellectual capacity necessitating full-time care. It outlines "Standalone" Plans as independent policies where benefits do not affect each other, and "Structured through superannuation" indicates ownership by a fund trustee. The "Super Contribution Benefit Amount" includes monthly benefits plus inflation adjustments. "Superlink" allows connection between policies issued to a superannuation fund and outside it, ensuring maximum benefits do not exceed those of a single policy. "Terminally Ill" denotes a life expectancy of less than 12 months, with specific conditions for policies structured through superannuation.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled (Any Occupation)
content:
Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled when ‘Any Occupation’ is shown in your Policy Schedule means that solely because of Sickness or Injury and after all reasonable treatment and rehabilitation has been undertaken:
• the Life Insured has not been working in any occupation for three consecutive months and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in any occupation for which they are reasonably suited by training, education or experience which would pay remuneration at a rate greater than 25% of the Life Insured’s Earnings during their last 12 months of work; or
• the Life Insured has suffered permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25% and has not been working in any occupation, and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in any occupation for which they are reasonably suited by training, education or experience which would pay remuneration at a rate greater than 25% of the Life Insured’s Earnings during their last 12 months of work; or
• the Life Insured is Totally and Permanently Disabled under the ‘ADL’ definition.
When cover is structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity.
ai_summary: Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) under the 'Any Occupation' clause means that the Life Insured, due to Sickness or Injury and after reasonable treatment, must have not worked for three consecutive months and be deemed unlikely to work in any suitable occupation earning over 25% of their previous earnings, or have a permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25%. Additionally, if the coverage is through superannuation, the Life Insured must meet the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled (Own Occupation)
content:
Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled when ‘Own Occupation’ is shown in your Policy Schedule means that solely because of Sickness or Injury and after all reasonable treatment and rehabilitation has been undertaken:
• the Life Insured has not been working in their Own Occupation for three consecutive months and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in their Own Occupation; or
• the Life Insured has suffered permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25% and has not been working in any occupation, and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in any occupation for which they are reasonably suited by training, education or experience which would pay remuneration at a rate greater than 25% of the Life Insured’s Earnings during their last 12 months of work; or
• the Life Insured is Totally and Permanently Disabled under the ‘ADL’ definition.
ai_summary: Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) under the 'Own Occupation' clause means that the insured individual is deemed TPD if, due to sickness or injury, they have not worked in their own occupation for three consecutive months and are unlikely to return, or if they have a permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25% and cannot work in any occupation suited to their skills and experience, earning more than 25% of their previous income. Additionally, TPD may also be determined under the Activities of Daily Living (ADL) definition.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled
ai_summary: Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) is defined in the policy as the inability of the Life Insured to perform at least two of five Activities of Daily Living without assistance, or due to permanent conditions such as blindness, loss of limb use, significant cognitive impairment, or a severe mental disorder that meets specific diagnostic criteria after Maximum Medical Improvement. This definition is applicable when indicated in the Policy Schedule or under the TPD ADL criteria.

content:
The Life Insured has a diagnosed mental disorder and meets at least four of the following:
• Self-care and independent living: Cannot live independently without regular support. Needs prompting to shower daily and wear clean clothes. Is not able to prepare own meals and frequently miss meals if not prompted to eat. Requires family member or community nurse visits at least 3 times every week to ensure minimum level of hygiene and nutrition.
• Social and/or recreational activities: Rarely goes out to social and/or recreational events, and only when prompted by a family member or a close friend. Not actively involved, remains quiet and withdrawn.
• Travel: Cannot travel away from own residence without support person due to severe anxiety or cognitive impairment.
• Social functioning: Unable to form or sustain long term relationships and loss of most pre-existing relationships (e.g. lost partner, close friends). Unable to care for dependants (e.g. own children, elderly parent).
• Concentration: Can only read a few lines of text before losing concentration. Has difficulty following simple instructions. Concentration deficits obvious even during brief conversation. Needs regular assistance from relatives or community services.
If the Life Insured permanently satisfies or meets the Mental Illness categories above, it must be solely due to a mental disorder diagnosed on a recognised diagnostic system.
ai_summary: To qualify for benefits under the mental illness categories, the Life Insured must have a diagnosed mental disorder and meet at least four specified criteria, including significant impairments in self-care, social functioning, travel, and concentration. These conditions must result in an inability to live independently, maintain relationships, or perform daily activities without regular support, and must be based on a recognized diagnostic system.

Subheading: Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled

Totally Unable to Work means that solely because of Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is:
• not working in any capacity (this includes full-time, part-time and casual, whether or not for remuneration;
ai_summary: "Totally Unable to Work" refers to a condition where the Life Insured is unable to engage in any form of employment—full-time, part-time, or casual—due to Sickness or Injury, regardless of whether they receive remuneration. content: Underwriting is a process by which we assess risks associated with your application for insurance. The Underwriting process is based on the life to be insured’s health and other relevant factors, such as occupation, pursuits and income.
ai_summary: Underwriting is the process of evaluating the risks linked to an insurance application, taking into account the insured individual's health, occupation, activities, and income. This assessment is crucial for determining coverage eligibility and premium rates.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: Unemployed and Unemployment mean that the Life Insured is not employed or working in any Working Occupation. It does not include sick leave, sabbatical, long service, maternity or paternity leave.
ai_summary: In the context of this insurance document, "Unemployed" and "Unemployment" refer to the status of the Life Insured when they are not engaged in any Working Occupation. This definition explicitly excludes periods of sick leave, sabbatical, long service leave, and maternity or paternity leave, which do not qualify as unemployment for insurance purposes.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Waiting Period means the period between the Life Insured becoming Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work, and the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit becoming payable.
If the Life Insured does not consult a Medical Practitioner concerning the Sickness or Injury causing disability within seven days of the Sickness starting or the Injury occurring, the Waiting Period will start when the Life Insured consults a Medical Practitioner.
ai_summary: The Waiting Period is the time frame between when the Life Insured becomes Totally or Partially Unable to Work and when the respective benefits become payable. If the Life Insured fails to consult a Medical Practitioner within seven days of the onset of Sickness or Injury, the Waiting Period will commence upon the first consultation with a Medical Practitioner.

ai_summary: In insurance terms, "War or an act of war" refers to armed aggression, regardless of whether it is officially declared, conducted by a country or organization, and opposed by another country or organization. This definition is crucial for determining coverage exclusions related to war-related events in insurance policies.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
The following definitions have been reproduced from SIS. You should be aware that if any of these definitions are changed in SIS, the corresponding definition reproduced here will be obsolete and replaced by the amended definition in SIS.

Permanent Incapacity in relation to a member of a superannuation fund means ill-health (whether physical or mental), where the trustee is reasonably satisfied that the member is unlikely, because of the ill-health, to engage in gainful employment for which the member is reasonably qualified by education, training or experience.

Temporary Incapacity in relation to a member of a superannuation fund who has ceased to be gainfully employed (including a member who has ceased temporarily to receive any gain or reward under a continuing arrangement for the member to be gainfully employed), means ill-health (whether physical or mental) that caused the member to cease to be gainfully employed but does not constitute Permanent Incapacity.

Terminal Medical Condition exists in relation to a member of a superannuation fund at a particular time if the following circumstances exist:
• two registered medical practitioners have certified, jointly or separately, that the person suffers from an illness, or has incurred an injury, that is likely to result in the death of the person within a period (the certification period) that ends not more than 24 months after the date of the certification;
• at least one of the registered medical practitioners is a specialist practicing in an area related to the illness or injury suffered by the person;
• for each of the certificates, the certification period has not ended.
ai_summary: This section outlines key definitions from the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act (SIS) relevant to superannuation fund members. "Permanent Incapacity" refers to a member's ill-health that prevents them from engaging in gainful employment for which they are qualified. "Temporary Incapacity" describes a member's ill-health that has caused them to cease gainful employment but does not qualify as Permanent Incapacity. A "Terminal Medical Condition" is defined as an illness or injury likely to result in death within 24 months, certified by two registered medical practitioners, including at least one specialist. Changes to these definitions in SIS will render the corresponding definitions in this document obsolete.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: 9.3 Critical Illness events and specified condition definition
content:
Angioplasty means the actual undergoing of Coronary Artery Angioplasty to correct a narrowing or blockage of one or more coronary arteries.

Angioplasty for Triple Vessel Disease means the actual undergoing for the first time of coronary artery angioplasty to correct a narrowing or blockage in three or more of the following major arteries in a single procedure:
• left main coronary artery;
• left anterior descending coronary artery;
• left circumflex coronary artery;
• right coronary artery.
In the event that not all coronary arteries can be corrected in a single procedure and a second procedure is required, a benefit will be payable provided the second procedure occurs no more than two months after the first.

Aortic Surgery (for specified conditions) means surgery to repair or correct an aortic aneurysm, an aortic dissection, an obstruction of the aorta, a coarctation of the aorta or traumatic Injury to the aorta. For the purpose of this definition, aorta means aortic arch, ascending aorta and descending aorta, but not its branches.

Aplastic Anaemia (requiring treatment) means bone marrow failure resulting in at least two of the following:
• anaemia;
• neutropenia; or
• thrombocytopenia; and
requiring one of the following:
• blood product transfusion;
• immunosuppressive agents; or
• bone marrow transplantation.

Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit) means a non-cancerous tumour of the brain (excludes cranial nerves), meninges, pituitary gland or spinal cord, resulting in an irreversible neurological deficit which has caused:
• permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25%; or
• the Life Insured to be totally and permanently unable to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living.
The presence of the underlying tumour must be confirmed by CT Scan, MRI or other imaging studies.
ai_summary: Section 9.3 defines critical illness events related to specific medical conditions covered by the insurance policy. Angioplasty refers to the procedure correcting coronary artery blockages, with benefits applicable for multiple vessel treatments if a second procedure occurs within two months. Aortic Surgery covers repairs for various aortic conditions, while Aplastic Anaemia requires treatment for bone marrow failure manifesting in specific blood deficiencies. Additionally, a Benign Brain Tumour must result in irreversible neurological deficits, confirmed by imaging, to qualify for benefits, necessitating a minimum impairment level or total inability to perform daily activities.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
Cysts, granulomas, vascular aneurysms or haematomas are not covered.

**Blindness (permanent)** means the permanent and irrecoverable loss of sight (whether aided or unaided) in both eyes as a result of Sickness or Injury to the extent that visual acuity in both eyes, on a Snellen Scale after correction by suitable lens is less than 6/60, or to the extent that the visual field is reduced to 20 degrees or less of arc.
ai_summary: **Blindness (permanent)** is defined as the irreversible loss of sight in both eyes due to Sickness or Injury, where visual acuity is less than 6/60 on the Snellen Scale, or where the visual field is reduced to 20 degrees or less. Notably, conditions such as cysts, granulomas, vascular aneurysms, or haematomas are explicitly excluded from coverage.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
**Cancer (of specified criteria)** means any malignant tumours diagnosed with histological or cytological confirmation and characterised by:
• the uncontrolled growth of malignant cells; and
• invasion and destruction of normal tissue beyond the basement membrane.

The term malignant tumour includes lymphoma (including Hodgkin’s and non-Hodgkin’s disease), leukaemia, multiple myeloma and malignant bone marrow disorders.

The following are not covered:
• All tumours which are histologically described as any of the following:
a. pre-malignant;
b. non-invasive (includes tumours that are classified as Tis, Cis or pTa unless stated otherwise);
c. low-grade or high-grade dysplasia; or
d. borderline or low malignant potential.
• All carcinoma in situ except the following:
a. Carcinoma in situ of the breast which requires the removal of the entire breast.
b. Carcinoma of the breast which requires breast conserving surgery with either radiotherapy or chemotherapy.
c. Carcinoma in situ of the testicle that requires removal of the entire testicle.
• All skin melanomas unless the melanoma:
a. has evidence of metastasis;
b. is at least Clark level 3;
c. is showing signs of ulceration; or
d. is greater than 1.0mm maximum thickness using the Breslow method.
• All non-melanoma skin cancers unless they have spread to the bone, lymph node or other distant organs.
• Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia unless it has progressed to Rai stage 1 or more.
• All prostatic cancers unless the prostate cancer:
a. has a Gleason score of 6 or more; or
b. requires major interventional therapy including radiotherapy, chemotherapy, biological response modifiers or any other major treatment to arrest the spread of malignancy.
ai_summary: The term "Cancer (of specified criteria)" refers to malignant tumors confirmed by histological or cytological diagnosis, characterized by uncontrolled cell growth and tissue invasion. Coverage excludes pre-malignant tumors, non-invasive tumors, low-grade dysplasia, and certain carcinomas in situ, with specific exceptions for breast and testicular cancers. Additionally, skin melanomas are only covered if they meet certain criteria, while non-melanoma skin cancers are excluded unless they have metastasized. Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia is covered only if it progresses to Rai stage 1 or higher, and prostatic cancers require a Gleason score of 6 or more or major treatment to be eligible for coverage.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content:
If a surgical procedure is performed, it must be considered appropriate and necessary to arrest the spread of malignancy.

**Carcinoma In Situ (of specified site)** means the Life Insured has a carcinoma in situ, characterised by a focal autonomous new growth of carcinomatous cells, which has not yet resulted in the invasion and destruction of normal tissues beyond the basement membrane. The tumour must be classified as Tis according to the TNM staging method or FIGO Stage 0.

Only Carcinomas In Situ of the following sites are covered:
• Breast
• Cervix (Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN) classified as CIN-1 and CIN-2 are excluded).
• Endometrium
• Fallopian Tube (the tumour must be limited to the tubal mucosa)
• Ovary
• Penis
• Perineum
• Testicle
• Vagina
• Vulva
ai_summary: Carcinoma In Situ (of specified site) refers to a localized cancer characterized by abnormal cell growth that has not invaded surrounding tissues, classified as Tis in the TNM staging or FIGO Stage 0. Coverage is limited to specific sites, including the breast, cervix (excluding certain CIN classifications), endometrium, fallopian tube, ovary, penis, perineum, testicle, vagina, and vulva, with the requirement that any surgical intervention must be deemed appropriate and necessary to prevent malignancy progression.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: **Cardiomyopathy (permanent)** means a disease of the heart muscle characterised by structural, functional and/or electrophysiological dysfunction of the heart muscle, resulting in significant permanent and irreversible cardiac impairment to the degree of at least Class 3 of the New York Heart Association classification of cardiac impairment.
ai_summary: **Cardiomyopathy (permanent)** refers to a heart muscle disease that leads to significant and irreversible impairment of cardiac function, classified as at least Class 3 according to the New York Heart Association. This definition is crucial for insurance coverage, as it outlines the severity of the condition necessary for claims related to permanent heart dysfunction.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: **Chronic Kidney Failure (undergoing permanent dialysis)** means undergoing permanent dialysis treatment prescribed by renal physician due to impairment of total kidney function to a severity constituting end stage kidney failure.
ai_summary: Chronic Kidney Failure (undergoing permanent dialysis) refers to a medical condition where an individual requires ongoing dialysis treatment as prescribed by a renal physician, due to severe impairment of kidney function that qualifies as end-stage kidney failure. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for insurance benefits related to kidney-related treatments and care.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Chronic Liver Failure (resulting in permanent symptoms)
content: **Chronic Liver Failure (resulting in permanent symptoms)** means end-stage decompensated liver failure characterised by the presence of liver cirrhosis and development of complications of cirrhosis, including jaundice, ascites and/or encephalopathy.
ai_summary: Chronic Liver Failure, as defined in the insurance document, refers to end-stage decompensated liver failure marked by liver cirrhosis and complications such as jaundice, ascites, and encephalopathy, which result in permanent symptoms. This definition is crucial for determining coverage and benefits related to liver-related health conditions within the insurance policy.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
Subheading: Chronic Lung Failure (on permanent oxygen therapy)
content:
**Chronic Lung Failure (on permanent oxygen therapy)** means end-stage lung disease with a consistent pulmonary function test result of:
• FEV1 less than 40% predicted; or
• a DLCO less than 40% predicted; and
• on permanent oxygen therapy.
ai_summary: Chronic Lung Failure (on permanent oxygen therapy) is defined as end-stage lung disease characterized by a pulmonary function test showing either an FEV1 less than 40% predicted or a DLCO less than 40% predicted, coupled with the requirement of permanent oxygen therapy. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for specific insurance benefits related to severe respiratory conditions.

Document_Name: Accelerated Protection Combined Product Disclosure Statement and Policy Document
content: **Coma (of specified severity)** means a state of unconsciousness which requires mechanical ventilation by means of tracheal intubation for at least three consecutive days (72 hours).
ai_summary: "Coma (of specified severity)" is defined as a state of unconsciousness necessitating mechanical ventilation through tracheal intubation for a minimum duration of 72 hours, which may impact eligibility for certain insurance benefits related to critical illness or disability coverage.
